Snake.desc: Lurkers in the shadows, the renegades of Sváfnir have no interest in preserving their honor, which gives them a solid tactical advantage. Using stealth, surprise and theft, they can unceasingly impair rival forces while their young chief Signy only grows stronger through the years.

line0.desc: You don't have access to [Fame] but can copy Knowledge from any clan you encounter.

line1.desc: You start with your warchief, the young [WarchiefSnake]. She grows up each year, getting stronger and gaining new powers.

line2.desc: [WarchiefSnake] can use [ScorchedEarth] to gain military advantage and steal natural resources from neutral zones. You can burn more zones as she grows stronger.

line3.desc: You can build [SkirmishCenter]s.

Dragon.name: Dragon
Dragon.title: The Clan of the Dragon
Dragon.desc: Exhausters of life, Nidhogg's followers exploit thralls to fuel their ravenous economy and human sacrifice to produce the wicked dragon essence. This sinister power can ultimately turn them into the dreadful dragonkins, revealing their inhumanity.

line0.desc: You start with a [SacrificialPyre]. You can build [DragonmenCamp]s instead of other military camps.

line1.desc: You start with ::value:: [Slave]s, which collect [Food] and can be assigned to buildings to increase the workers production.

line2.desc: Your civilians can go into neutral territory and suffer no [Happy] or production penalty for being wounded.

Horse.name: Horse
Horse.title: The Clan of the Horse
Horse.desc: Supreme craftspersons, the artisans of Svadilfari are known for their solid defenses and efficient building maintenance. In Völund's forge, their tireless chiefs Eitria and Brok shape the wondrous tools and relics which bring glory to this people.

line0.desc: You don't have access to [AllMines]s, [Miner]s or [Smith]s.

line1.desc: You have two warchiefs who can be summoned from [ForgeHorse] without [Iron].

line2.desc: Your Warchiefs can build, repair, mine, and forge ::percent:: faster.

Kraken.name: Kraken
Kraken.title: The Clan of the Kraken
Kraken.desc: Wielders of fate, the mighty norns of Lyngbakr master the occult forces of the wyrd and can turn into fierce valkyries. The clan of the Kraken, fearful worshipper of the brutal sea, thrives on its fish-filled coasts but knows its dangers too well to sail offshore.

line0.desc: You can't build [Port]s and access the Trade Victory, but [Fishery]s are ::percent:: more effective and can be used to fish both in lakes and the sea.

line1.desc: On non-coastal zones, colonization and building costs are ::percent:: more expensive, and units' attack power is reduced by ::inv_percent1::.

line2.desc:
The [Horgr] replaces the [Tavern] and produces [Prescience].
When producing a positive amount, the Kraken will send you new villagers.

line3.desc:
You start with ::value:: [SpecterWarrior].
You can have more by building [Horgr]s and having negative [Prescience].

line4.desc: [Seeress]s can evolve into [NornArmor]s.

Ox.name: Ox
Ox.title: The Clan of the Ox
Ox.desc: Forces of nature, the oxes of Himminbrjotir are large, robust, efficient, and led by an even more powerful chief, Torfin. The devotion of his clan can bring this fallen god back to life, allowing him to reclaim his ancient equipment from mythical battlegrounds.

line0.desc: Your warchief is the powerful [OxHero]. He can find and equip [Artifact]s.

line1.desc: Your units are tougher, larger and eat more than the other clans, and have a ::percent:: attack power and defense bonus.

line2.desc: Specialized civilian units have a ::percent:: production bonus, except [RuneMaster]s.

line3.desc: Any building can hold only one unit, [House]s hold less people.

line4.desc: [OxThrone] produce +::value:: [Lore] while [OxHero] is not summoned.

Lynx.name: Lynx
Lynx.title: The Clan of the Lynx
Lynx.desc: Mythical hunters, the arrow-shooting trackers of the Lynx gain strength by collecting sacred trophies on their preys. Their chief Mielikki, tamer of the sacred felines Brundr and Kaelinn, has the ability to bring back the mythical beasts she slayed for one ultimate battle.

line0.desc: Earn [HuntTrophy]s on animal kills.

line1.desc: The [Archery] replaces the [AxeCenter].

line2.desc: You can summon [LynxBrown] and [LynxWhite] to your [Archery]. [LynxHero], the Beastmaster is weaker than other warchiefs but does not cost [Iron].

line3.desc: The Path of the Hunter replaces Military Paths. Spend [HuntTrophy]s to unlock powerful abilities for [LynxBrown], [LynxWhite] and the [Tracker]s.

Squirrel.name: Squirrel
Squirrel.title: The Clan of the Squirrel
Squirrel.desc: Cunning and bountiful, the gluttons of Ratatoskr draw their vigor from the fine cuisine of the divine cook Andhrimnir. To sustain their epicurean lifestyle during winter, they are especially efficient in autumn. Their prodigality can also benefit their allies, but beware; they are astute manipulators.

line0.desc: The clan doesn't [Feast] but instead gather [Ingredients] in its territory, depending on the zone type, to prepare different [Meal]s.

line1.desc: The [Stove] replaces the [Tavern]. [SquirrelHero] is your warchief and can be assigned to it to produce more [Ingredients].

line2.desc: The clan hoards greedily in anticipation of winter 2 months before it starts and can count on a ::percent:: increase in production during this period. However, they have a harder time during winter itself as they consume more [Food] and [Wood].

line3.desc: The clan can achieve its specific Ratatoskr Victory.

Rat.name: Rat
Rat.title: The Clan of the Rat
Rat.desc: Relentless survivors, the houseless outcasts of Dodsvagr strive without a break, for they have learned to use pain, hardship and death to their advantage. Led by the warmaiden Eir, their shamans can mend wounds as surely as they can inflict them.

line0.desc: The clan has more villagers but they arrive wounded. Wounded units do not count for [Happy] requirement.

line1.desc: The clan doesn't have access to [House]s, but all non-mystic buildings provide housing. Extra villagers wait in your [PopReserve].

line2.desc: The [HealerCamp] replaces the [HealerHut].

line3.desc: When the clan units kill foes or die, the corpses are cremated in a [Purification] at a [HealerCamp].

line4.desc: [Overwork] replaces the [Feast].

Eagle.name: Eagle
Eagle.title: The Clan of the Eagle
Eagle.desc: Carried by the winds, the agile explorers of Hraesvelg do not need to occupy a large territory, for they will easily venture outside to gather resources. Their profound knowledge of the terrain and their ability to exploit it to its fullest allow them to survive in the most desertic areas. They are led by Grif, the sole survivor of a fallen clan.

line0.desc: The [Falconry] replaces the [ScoutCamp] and train [Falconer]s who explore and reveal [Treasure]s on the map over time.

line1.desc: You start with 1 [Hawk]. They turn a cleared zone into a [Boneyard], providing natural resources from the zone and healing your units.

line2.desc: [Falconry]s require no building slot and increase the maximum number of [Hawk]s you can send on a [Boneyard].

line3.desc: You gain no [Fame] for colonizing new zones.

Lion.name: Lion
Lion.title: The Clan of the Lion
Lion.desc: Protected by their glorious forts, noble lords and blessed relics, the dominions of Neustria have found unity under the Lion's banner. Even in struggle, its pious subjects will never lose faith, for they know it is with perseverance that the cities and cathedrals of stone are built.

line0.desc: Zones with military camps gain +::value:: [Comfort].

line1.desc: Killing a foe generates [Faith] if [LionHero] takes part in the fight.

line2.desc: Military units can be recruited using [Faith] instead of [Money].

Carolingians.name: Lion
Carolingians.title: The Kingdom of the Lion
Carolingians.desc: Protected by their glorious forts, noble lords and blessed relics, the dominions of Neustria have found unity under the Lion's banner. Even in struggle, its pious subjects will never lose faith, for they know it is with perseverance that the cities and cathedrals of stone are built.

line0.desc: The [CarolingianTownHall] is your main building. It spawns new subjects, your base unit.

line1.desc: Subjects produce [Faith] instead of [Food].

line2.desc: Buildings have no builder nor worker limit, but you can only assign additional workers if the [Comfort] in the zone is sufficient.

line3.desc: Workers in a zone with ::value1:: [Comfort] or more have a ::percent:: production bonus and ::percent_value2:: bonus population growth.

line4.desc: The [CarolingianTownHall] protects all subjects in its zone from the cold and feeds them until winter comes. It also heals units assigned to it.

line5.desc: Building upgrades cost less [Stone]. It is not necessary to upgrade the [CarolingianTownHall] first.

line6.desc: Feasts give 10% bonus to all production and 2 [Happy] and apply [GreatLivability] to all of your zones.

WeaponDef.name: Tyr's Combat Gloves
WeaponDef.desc: Increases attack power by ::percent::. Reduces projectile damage by ::inv_percent1::.

ArmorDef.name: Tyr's Chain Pauldron
ArmorDef.desc: Increases defense by ::percent:: and health by ::health1::.

LeggingDef.name: Tyr's Charge Leggings
LeggingDef.desc: Adds a ::percent_value:: chance to evade attacks and increases move speed by ::percent1:: in allied territory.

WeaponAtk.name: Heimdall's Sparring Gloves
WeaponAtk.desc: Increases attack by ::percent:: and attack speed by ::percent1::.

ArmorAtk.name: Heimdall's Hunting Pauldron
ArmorAtk.desc: Increases your defense by ::percent::. Reflects ::percent_value1:: of the received attacks.

LeggingAtk.name: Heimdall's Traveler Leggings
LeggingAtk.desc: Unlock the [OxHeroAoE] passive ability, which allows area of effect attacks. Increase move speed by ::percent:: in neutral or enemy territory.

line0.text: Venison & Ratatouille

line1.text: Hearty Venison & Ratatouille

line2.text: Seasoned Venison & Ratatouille

line3.text: Chef's Choice Venison & Ratatouille

RecipeMiniFeast.desc: A plate of vegetables and mushrooms with strips of deer meat. While it doesn't look like much, most Vikings are grateful for it as it keeps their belly full and their spirits high.
RecipeMiniFeast.flavor: Ratatouille is actually a recently invented dish, originating from Southeast France. It also has nothing to do with rats.

line0.text: Fish Soup

line1.text: Hearty Fish Soup

line2.text: Seasoned Fish Soup

line3.text: Chef's Choice Fish Soup

RecipeHealth.desc: Fish, vegetables and mushrooms cooked to a perfection in sea water, which most Vikings will find delicious, provided they don't mind a strong iodized flavour. Very healthy!
RecipeHealth.flavor: Do try "bouillabaisse" if you ever visit France!

line0.text: Breaded Fish Fillets

line1.text: Hearty Breaded Fish Fillets

line2.text: Seasoned Breaded Fish Fillets

line3.text: Chef's Choice Breaded Fish Fillets

RecipeCraft.desc: Breaded fish fillets pan-fried with a bit of oil and served with fresh vegetables. A light, healthy dish which keeps both mind and body sharp as a pickaxe.

line0.text: Meat Stew

line1.text: Hearty Meat Stew

line2.text: Seasoned Meat Stew

line3.text: Chef's Choice Meat Stew

RecipeWinter.desc: A delicious mix of venison, vegetables and mushrooms, simmered for hours in a cookpot and served piping hot. Perfect for sustaining those long, cold winter nights.
RecipeWinter.flavor: In French, the name of this rather delicious dish is "daube", which, oddly, is also used as slang for a bad movie, game, book etc.

line0.text: Seafood Buffet

line1.text: Hearty Seafood Buffet

line2.text: Seasoned Seafood Buffet

line3.text: Chef's Choice Seafood Buffet

RecipeDefense.desc: A particularly filling buffet of seafood, vegetables and mushrooms. Not exactly the meal you'll want to eat before taking a hike, but very fortifying and comforting.
RecipeDefense.flavor: Vikings probably didn't consume seafood raw and therefore missed out on sushis and the likes.

line0.text: Forest Barbecue

line1.text: Hearty Forest Barbecue

line2.text: Seasoned Forest Barbecue

line3.text: Chef's Choice Forest Barbecue

RecipeAttack.desc: Wild boar ribs slightly caramelized with mead, served with roasted vegetables and mushrooms, for those Vikings who don't skimp on proteins.
RecipeAttack.flavor: SPAM! SPAM! SPAM! SPAM! LOVELY S-P-A-A-A-A-M, WONDERFUL S-P-A-A-A-A-M!

line0.text: Banquet of Valhöll

RecipeVictory.desc: A wide variety of lavish meals, served cold, warm or piping hot. Odin himself would drool before such a feast!

line0.text: Banquet

RecipeAdvisor.desc: This exuberant cuisine surpasses the most profligate meal one can dream of. That should suffice to convince Rig that you are more likely to survive this siege than he is.

WinterResist.desc: Reduces [Food] and [Wood] consumption during winter by ::percent::.

NewVillagerSpeed.desc: New villagers will arrive at the [TownHall] ::percent:: faster.

HealthRegen.desc: Units in your territory or neutral zones will slowly regenerate their health over time.

ScoutDamageImmune.desc: [Scout] are immune to damage while scouting.

Victory.desc: The clan of Squirrel and its allies win the game.

line0.text: I am Rig, son of the High King Hargurorf, and this is my saga.

line1.text: It all began... one fateful day...

line2.text: My father had gathered all his Jarls to make an announcement of the utmost importance.

line3.text: We were to embark for the wondrous lands of Northgard; riches, conquest and glory awaited us on this mysterious new continent.

line4.text: But the Norns had other plans for us...

line5.text: Dozens of armed men suddenly poured into the Hall and put an abrupt end to our ambitions... and to our lives.

line6.text: They were mercenaries led by a man named Hagen, from the Clan of the Raven.

line7.text: In a matter of minutes, we were all slaughtered like sheep.

line8.text: All... but me. Barely conscious and vastly outnumbered, I had no way to fight back, so I feigned death.

line9.text: I seethed as he stole the map of Northgard and ripped the Regal Horn from my father's throne, a family heirloom and the very symbol of our royalty.

line10.text: I had to avenge my father... and reclaim my kinghood!

Journey.name: Exodus
Journey.desc: We have safely escaped to a remote region. We must now reach the shores of Northgard.

line0.desc: Reach the shore to the north.

line1.desc: Build a [Port].

line2.desc: Acquire a minimum of ::value:: [Food].

line3.desc: Explore all the [BrokenHouse]s.

line4.desc: Build the [Port] before Year ::value::.

line0.text: I had no strength left when I encountered a group of runaways of the Stag Clan led by a proud young man named Brand.

line1.text: Hagen's men had set his town aflame and he had nothing left, not even his father, the clan's Jarl, who had died at the hands of the fiend just like mine.

line2.text: Our common enemy had sailed for Northgard, of which he now had a map. All I could think about was finding him to avenge my father and retrieve the Regal Horn.

line0.text: Glad to see you back on your feet, my lord. I'm surprised at how fast you recovered.

line1.text: I suppose rage is an excellent healer. Still, we've wasted enough time already. We must go after Hagen as soon as possible.

line2.text: Indeed, time is of the essence. Our camp is far from the enemy, but we are marooned in an unknown province on the outskirts of your kingdom.

line3.text: I shall prove myself worthy of their trust. However impatient I am to get even with that scum, my priority is to ensure their survival.

line4.text: Very good. Your restraint does you honor. Besides, none of us will be getting revenge if we starve to death first.

line5.text: Speaking of which, there will be no shortage of mouths to feed, so let us seek out food. Wood is also a vital resource, being used for both heating and construction.

line6.text: We must also leave the continent and set sail for Northgard. We shall need a proper shore to go out to sea.

line7.text: You are quite right. I suggest you instruct villagers to build a scout camp and assign them as scouts, so that they may explore the region.

line8.text: Hmm, the air is getting colder... winter is almost upon us.

line9.text: Indeed, my lord. We should expect food to be scarcer, and our people will consume more firewood to heat their homes.

line10.text: Our military troops will also be weakened by the cold. It might not be the best time to fight.

line11.text: My lord, reconnaissance of the area has revealed an abandoned cottage.

line12.text: Perhaps we should order a scout to search it. They might be able to salvage some resources.

line13.text: Agreed. We will have to colonize the area before they can explore the ruins, however.

line14.text: My lord, one scout claims to have found a suitable coast for the construction of a port.

line15.text: Excellent. We should colonize the area leading up to this shore so that our builders can reach it and get to work.

line16.text: At last! Thanks to your efforts, our clan can now put out to sea.

line17.text: Anchors aweigh, proud Vikings! We sail for Northgard!

line18.text: Your end draws near, Hagen.

line0.text: Getting Started

line1.text: You are in a safe, remote area. Your goal here is to meet the basic survival needs of your clan: [Food], [Wood] and [House]s.

line2.text: Be sure to assign [Scout]s so that they can explore the region, and then expand your territory by colonizing nearby areas. Find a shore to embark in search of undiscovered lands.

Foothold.name: Foothold
Foothold.desc: Northgard is a harsh continent. We must tame these lands, lest we be forgotten by history.

line0.desc: Colonize ::value:: territories.

line1.desc: Reach ::value:: [Fame].

line2.desc: Send your military units to kill all [Wolf]s around Halvard's settlement.

line3.desc: Reach ::value:: [Happy].

line4.desc: Destroy all [WolvesCave]s.

line5.desc: Trade [Food] and [Wood] with Halvard via 2 Trade Routes for at least ::value:: month(s) each.

line0.text: My companions' eyes were shining with ambition; they were eager to set foot on the untamed lands of Northgard and reap its wonders.

line1.text: But my heart was tormented by a darker appetite.

line2.text: Vengeance.

line0.text: Land ho! Finally, we set foot on Northgard!

line1.text: My lord, we have dismantled our longships and used the scrap lumber to build a town hall on the shore.

line2.text: There is no turning back now. Thank you for your dedication.

line3.text: We await your orders to claim the area and expand our clan.

line4.text: There is much to be done. We must colonize the surrounding area to expand our living space and find resources...

line5.text: ...and we need to raise our fame if we hope to stake a rightful claim to the region.

line6.text: Please stay safe and lead us to victory, my lord!

line7.text: What is this wretched creature?

line8.text: Could that be... a draugr?

line9.text: I have heard old men's tales of undead warriors, but I never gave them much credit. Apparently I was wrong.

line10.text: At any rate, we should defend our people and slay this fiendish abomination!

line11.text: We just discovered a mineral deposit. These come in two types: stone and iron ore.

line12.text: Both are important resources, and both can be extracted by miners. Build a mine and assign villagers to them.

line13.text: Stone can be used to improve our buildings. Iron allows us to make our tools better, as well as to rearm a bannerman–such as myself–if they should fall in battle.

line14.text: Keep in mind that a deposit is finite and typically holds little ore. Be sure to make good use of it.

line15.text: My lord, we have encountered another clan. What shall we do?

line16.text: Are they with that scum Hagen?

line17.text: We come in peace! I am Halvard of Heidrun, the Goat Clan. We mean you no harm! Please offer us assistance!

line18.text: Greetings, Halvard of Heidrun. I am Rig, son of the late High King Hargurorf. What ails you?

line19.text: My deepest condolences, my young lord. We too have lost much of late.

line20.text: Our journey went awry and... well, to be brief, we are now shipwrecked on a desolate shore.

line21.text: We have nothing left and will soon give in to the wilderness... I beg of you, help us!

line22.text: We will lend you our aid. What would you have us do?

line23.text: Thank you! It should not be too much trouble...

line24.text: Your warriors need only exterminate the wolves threatening our fragile camp.

line25.text: We've acquired enough Lore to develop a new skill. Please choose wisely, for it will have consequences for our expansion... and our survival.

line26.text: It is crucial that we study any Runestone or Circle of Stones we encounter. It will allow our Loremasters to gather Lore and develop our knowledge.

line27.text: Young lord! The beasts are upon us! We need assistance! Please send reinforcements at your earliest opportunity!

line28.text: My lord, I am delighted to report that Halvard's camp is now safe from any beastly threat.

line29.text: Excellent. Please make sure his people receive the food they need. And tend to their wounded.

line30.text: On behalf of the Heidrun Clan, I would like to express our most heartfelt gratitude. We would have been doomed without you.

line31.text: From now until the end of time, you can count on the help and loyalty of the Goat Clan. I hereby solemnly pledge my allegiance to you.

line32.text: Glorious! Our Clan has reached a notable level of fame. Our influence over the region is strong, and our people's hearts are filled with pride!

line33.text: Magnificent! Our territory has reached a substantial size. The populace will be able to thrive here after we leave for the next region.

line34.text: Woe is us! You won't make it in time... We are doomed. Yet we go to the grave without resentment. May you succeed where we failed!

line0.text: The Clan of Eikthyrnir

line1.text: The Clan of the Stag enjoys extra resources as it develops and thrives.

line2.text: They also excel when it comes to [Happy] and [Fame], so take advantage of these assets to expand in peace.

Outpost.name: Settlement
Outpost.desc: Hagen is reported to have settled in the region. We must strengthen our position while trying to find him.

line0.desc: Build a [Tavern] and an [Temple].

line1.desc: Reach ::value:: [Fame].

line2.desc: Destroy the Raven Outpost.

line3.desc: Hold ::value:: [Sheep] in [Sheepfold]s at any one time.

line4.desc: Kill all [Valkyrie]s.

line0.text: The sons of Heidrun had been shipwrecked on an inhospitable coast, but we arrived just in time to save them from the fangs of the wolves.

line1.text: Halvard, their elderly leader, was so grateful he swore allegiance to me the moment we met.

line2.text: He readily agreed to share invaluable secrets about survival. Soon enough, we would be taming the wilderness.

line0.text: Hagen is out there somewhere. We need to find him and kill him.

line1.text: My lord, I understand your eagerness, but we must settle in enough to establish control over the new areas.

line2.text: This area would seem to suit our plans. We should absolutely settle here. Heidrun's followers are tough survivors, so allow us to lay the groundwork for your conquest of Northgard.

line3.text: Halvard is a reliable ally who is equally persistent and composed.

line4.text: Let him honor his debt and prove his allegiance to you. In the meantime, I will take my leave and attend to the business we discussed.

line5.text: Understood. Please travel safely, Brand.

line6.text: Fare thee well, my lord. I shall return soon.

line7.text: Halvard, you will assist me in this operation.

line8.text: Thank you, young lord. I will not disappoint you.

line9.text: Lo! A Valkyrie. Methinks Odin's maids could help us defeat our enemies.

line10.text: Wait, my lord. I am afraid something is wrong with these ones...

line11.text: Oh, indeed. What a tragedy. It seems these fair creatures have been tainted by some corrupt influence.

line12.text: There is naught we can do but put them out of their misery. However, we should expect them to be formidable foes.

line13.text: What are those ugly little critters?

line14.text: I believe those are kobolds. They were a rare sight back on the continent, but they seem to thrive here on Northgard.

line15.text: They are not aggressive, but they do exhibit territorial behavior. They will most certainly attack if we trespass.

line16.text: Hmm, would they accept to trade with us, I wonder?

line17.text: Young lord! We have spotted men from another clan. I think you are going to relish this.

line18.text: What? The Goats survived? I thought they'd ended up in the wolves' bellies. Halvard, ya senile billy goat, ya really are tough meat! Surrender now and I'll spare ya.

line19.text: No one is going to surrender, Hagen. Not even you will be given this chance. You killed my father. Prepare to die.

line20.text: The High King's son be here too? Oh my... Nuttin' quite went accordin' to plan. I thought I'd killed ya, but it matters no longer. I'll finish the job now.

line21.text: Overconfidence will only make it worse for you. You've accomplished but one thing: making more enemies than you already had.

line22.text: Halvard, there's been a change of plan. Our objective now is to destroy his outpost.

line23.text: That feathered scoundrel may be planning to harry us with mercenary raids. It might be wise to erect defense towers at the borders of our territory.

line24.text: Indeed. We should also improve our scout camp so that our scouts are able to perform reconnaissance in enemy territory.

line25.text: Ye never know when to quit, do ya? Well, can't say I didn't warn you lot.

line26.text: Mercenaries, your purses will be filled to the brim if ye defeat 'em! I won't be riskin' my life here. Fare thee well!

line27.text: No! Stay here, you coward!

line28.text: Young lord, Hagen seems willing to go all out on this. I do not think we can hold them off for long. I am so sorry we failed you!

line29.text: Do not lose hope, Halvard. Trust me when I say you'll live to see another day.

line30.text: I believe we arrived just in time.

line31.text: Just in time? We missed out on most of the bloodshed!

line32.text: Greetings, Egil of the Wolf Clan. I am Rig, son of High K-

line33.text: Right, good for you. There's still crows standing, so how's about we let our axes do the talking!

line34.text: Thank the gods for your intervention. I am truly grateful you risked your lives to save us.

line35.text: Wait, what? You mean we came here to save people?

line36.text: Let me guess: you stopped listening at "slaughtering mercenaries"?

line37.text: Not to sound ungrateful, but was that level of savagery really necessary?

line38.text: I'll be sure to give Hagen a hug from you right before I slay him.

line39.text: So much hubris and recklessness within one man... I pray you live long enough to reap the fruit of your victories.

line40.text: Fabulous! We've managed to build up a decent reputation in the region, and our Fame is substantial.

line41.text: We've done it! We built the Altar of Kings, one of the most magnificent monuments one could hope to erect!

line42.text: Not to mention the brewery. Our good people can now find relief after a hard day's labor. They are very grateful to you, young lord.

line43.text: My people's happiness is a priority of mine. Surviving is one thing–living is something else entirely.

line0.text: The Clan of Heidrun

line1.text: The Goat Clan benefits from [Sheep] farming, taking advantage of these animals by sheltering them in [Sheepfold]s (a building unique to them).

line2.text: Having mastered the science of food preservation, they can afford to organize hearty Feasts that will boost their [Happy] and productivity.

Settling.name: Trade War
Settling.desc: This estuary is a critical chokepoint for trade. We must establish a trading network that will allow us to provide supplies to our future expeditions.

line0.desc: Build a [Port] and complete it with a [Lighthouse].

line1.desc: Reach ::value:: [Prestige] with Great Trade Routes before the Raven Clan does.

line2.desc: Force the Raven Clan to surrender.

line3.desc: Trade with all neutral factions at the same time over ::value:: month(s).

line4.desc: Have 12 [Merchant]s and 6 [Sailor]s active at any one time.

line0.text: Hagen had eluded us, so Egil left to track him down himself. He was to send for me upon finding him.

line1.text: In the meantime, Brand and Halvard insisted we establish a far-reaching supply network for all our future expeditions throughout Northgard.

line2.text: This would be a war of another kind entirely, one to be fought with gold rather than steel.

line3.text: I just had to focus on the task at hand, waiting to hear from Egil.

line0.text: Here we are. Certainly an excellent spot to establish a commercial chokepoint.

line1.text: Let us roll up our sleeves. To be honest, I would rather not spill blood. 'Tis bad for business.

line2.text: Good day, my lords. I see we have all come to the same conclusion: this region should be the commercial nerve center for the victors.

line3.text: Greetings. You must be Liv of the Raven Clan, lieutenant to that scum Hagen. I would rather be your ally than your enemy, but the Norns seem to disagree.

line4.text: Do not expect mercy from me, Raven. Soon enough, all goods entering Northgard will have to go through us.

line5.text: Indeed, there is only room for one trade tycoon. And I'm afraid I cannot let you put a spoke in my wheel. Still, I wish you good luck.

line6.text: Refreshing to see that battles can still be fought without childish chest-thumping. We too bid you good fortune, for you will need it!

line7.text: We had better get started. The key to victory is to build a Longship Dock and a Lighthouse, then make use of great trade routes.

line8.text: Apologies, young lord, but should we not worry about gathering stone? Stone is instrumental in upgrading buildings.

line9.text: My lord, I just got word that we have no stone in our reserves. We should build a mine and gather some, as is it vital for building upgrades.

line10.text: I admit it had slipped my mind. Yes, we should find a deposit and exploit it as soon as possible. Then upgrade our buildings, of course.

line11.text: Well, winter is behind us, and we have some stone in store... Now we should try to upgrade as many buildings as possible.

line12.text: Good thinking. Upgrading is more than just a luxury–it is key to victory. It will allow us to affect more workers and make our activities more efficient.

line13.text: We probably won't be able to upgrade all our structures, though. We should carefully determine which are most important.

line14.text: And we should remember to keep mining iron, as well. Our workers could use better tools!

line15.text: Giants, how wonderful! Northgard is just full of surprises. Rather intimidating ones at that.

line16.text: The Jötnar are said to be formidable opponents. They are peaceful but will take any intrusion as an aggressive action. I strongly advise against antagonizing them.

line17.text: If they agree to trade with us, we could build a mutually beneficial relationship. It's worth trying. We should establish a route from a trading post.

line18.text: Our trade supremacy over the region is now established. Any resource that goes through this estuary will have to go through us.

line19.text: Congratulations, my lords. I have been bested, fair and square.

line20.text: I suspect my master will not take this kindly, however. So, do enjoy this hegemony of yours while it lasts.

line21.text: Well, this region has outlived its usefulness to me. I bid you farewell.

line22.text: I am less than eager to hear Hagen's reaction to this. No doubt I am in for an earful...

line23.text: What an uncanny reaction. She had fought with fierceness and resolve, and yet her praise seemed sincere.

line24.text: Brand, Halvard, I've just heard from Egil. He has tracked Hagen down to a region nearby, and so I shall join him now. I would ask you to fortify what we've built here.

line25.text: I am glad your revenge is at last within your reach. Be safe, my lord. We will join you as soon as we can.

line26.text: Do keep in mind: all our future operations can connect to this region by establishing a trade route from a trading post.

line27.text: It is done. Your control of the region is negligible. Oh, I will trade with you, but do not expect friendly prices!

line28.text: 'Tis a disaster, my lord! There is no way we can conquer Northgard after losing such a strategically vital chokepoint!

line29.text: All that effort... for naught!

line30.text: I am loath to report this, but Liv has finished building her Lighthouse. She is bound to launch major expeditions soon!

line31.text: This means building a Lighthouse of our own should be our top priority. We cannot afford to fall behind.

line32.text: Reports show that Liv has a good headstart. We should work twice as hard to keep from falling behind.

line33.text: Liv has taken the lead. We need to hurry and catch up with her!

line34.text: Curses! Liv is winning this war! Even if we put all our resources into the most prominent routes, we could not catch up with her.

line35.text: Young lord, I abhor the thought, but I fear we are fighting a losing battle. According to my calculations, Liv is so far ahead we cannot possibly catch up with her.

line36.text: I have reached the same conclusion. But there is still one way we can win this.

line37.text: Are you suggesting we harry her with our armed forces?

line39.text: I am. Attacking Liv now would force her to divert resources to defense. I do not suggest we try to defeat her militarily–we need only hinder her progress long enough to close the gap.

line40.text: She will most likely retaliate, but this is preferable to losing the region right away, which we are bound to do at this rate. Well thought out, my lord.

line41.text: This may well be the only viable strategy we have left. Nevertheless, we should expect a swift retaliation.

line42.text: Using force, are you? Perhaps I expected too much finesse from brutes like you. Boys will be boys, I suppose.

line43.text: Well, you shall have to negotiate with my mercenaries.

line44.text: Greetings, Liv. I'm afraid I must put an end to your business here. Steel beats gold.

line45.text: I cannot say I expected this outcome. 'Twas all fun and games, yet I fear someone may lose an eye. That's it, then. I humbly surrender.

line46.text: This is most awkward. To be honest, I didn't condone this military assault, but Lord Rig insisted on putting the war back in "trade war."

line47.text: I do not entirely subscribe to this definition of victory, but Lord Rig appears to believe that a trade war is still a war.

line48.text: Means to an end, perhaps. I can appreciate that. Well played, my lords.

line49.text: My lord, our business is doing quite well... I think we will soon reach our ultimate goal.

line50.text: You may be right, but we shouldn't rest on our laurels.

line0.text: Trade Victory

line1.text: The goal here is not to crush your foe by sheer force. Make contact with other clans, and assign [Sailor]s and [Merchant]s to establish trade routes with them.

line2.text: You must build a [Port], then add a [Lighthouse] to it, if you want to increase your influence and establish Great Trade Routes.

Skirmish.name: Punitive Expedition
Skirmish.desc: Egil has finally found Hagen. I am joining him to launch a punitive party. We must strike fast.

line0.desc: Find and kill Hagen before he gets reinforcements.

line1.desc: Destroy both secondary Raven Outposts.

line2.desc: Kill Hagen before Year ::value::.

line3.desc: Complete the mission without Egil being defeated.

line0.text: Egil was a fierce, ruthless man. His relentlessness on the battlefield often made his enemies believe he paid no mind to tactics.

line1.text: Granted, he never planned very far ahead, but he made up for it by adapting to any situation, no matter how complicated.

line2.text: It was a good thing too, because our "plan" was to raid a Raven settlement from the sea, claim it, then launch a punitive expedition against Hagen from there.

line0.text: Land ho! Draw your axes and brace yourselves!

line1.text: All right, boys, it's plundering time! CHAAAARGE!

line2.text: There–this area is now under our control.

line3.text: Warriors, we are here to ferret out that scum Hagen and slay him. I shall have my revenge!

line4.text: As much as I love a good brawl, we should probably maintain the element of surprise until the decisive strike.

line5.text: We'll claim their buildings, but making more is out of the question. Wars are won by leveling cities, not building them!

line6.text: Well, I see your point, but...

line7.text: Should we not at least ask the villagers to repair those buildings before they burn out entirely?

line8.text: I guess it wouldn't hurt. As long as I'm not the one doing the fixing. I'm better at wrecking stuff, anyway.

line9.text: Plus, I've got the munchies. Let's go find some grub where it is: in the wild. Wolves are tasty–if they don't eat you first.

line10.text: We must strike fast. Dawdling will only allow Hagen to regroup his forces.

line11.text: Darn! They've got reinforcements. Well, too late for finesse. CHARGE!

line12.text: We should colonize this area. There are some sheep there. We could slaughter them for food and get a nice boost from it.

line13.text: This outpost isn't worth it. My axes are itching to strike, but it's probably better to stay clear of it and remain unnoticed for now.

line14.text: Hagen is not here. We should maintain the element of surprise for as long as we can.

line15.text: At last, we're closing in on Hagen's settlement.

line16.text: Let us hit him again and again! He will join his ancestors in Helheim!

line17.text: And one outpost down! Hagen, we are coming for you!

line18.text: I'm unstoppable! Wish I could see Hagen's face right now.

line19.text: Well, well, well... We meet again, crow. Told you I wouldn't let it go.

line20.text: Like the obedient hound y'are. Let me talk to yer master–I've a proposition to make.

line21.text: I am here, Hagen. Nothing you say can possibly stop me from avenging my father.

line22.text: Ah, it looks like I arrived just in time.

line23.text: Liv, my dear apprentice! Help me! Kill these men!

line24.text: Not going to happen, Hagen. You've been bested, and I won't be on the losing side if I can help it. At least show some dignity.

line25.text: Liv, you despicable traitoress! You owe me everything! I made ya what you are!

line26.text: You're wrong. I did. You were but a stepping stone.

line27.text: C... curse you... Liv...

line28.text: Wow! That was cold, even by my standards.

line29.text: You just took away my sole opportunity to avenge my father! Egil, end her.

line30.text: With pleasure.

line31.text: Wait!

line32.text: I knew you would be upset, my lord, but hear me out! Hagen was a pathetic fool, but he was not the real menace.

line33.text: Go on...

line34.text: Let me pledge my allegiance to you, and I will reveal your true enemy. There is much I have to tell you...

line35.text: Egil, I'm beginning to worry about your strategy. We are running out of food, and Hagen will have reinforcements before long.

line36.text: Yeah, I hadn't planned this far. Let's hurry up and drive Hagen out now!

line37.text: Hmm... been a while since I heard from the outpost up north. I don't like it one bit...

line38.text: Liv, make yerself useful for once! Put together a party of mercenaries to check it out.

line40.text: Ya deaf, runt? Get a move on!

line0.text: The Clan of Fenrir

line1.text: The Wolf Clan lives off warfare and hunting. Salvage [Meat] directly from the [Wolf]s and [Bear]s you slay in the wild.

line2.text: Don't hesitate to be belligerent. Aggression is the clan's primary lifestyle–they even draw [Happy] from their military power!

Act1Ending.name: Liv's Revelations
Act1Ending.desc: Hagen is dead, but Liv's revelations have unveiled a greater threat and given us a new goal.

line0.text: Liv had taken us all by surprise! Despite our eventful history, I decided to give her a chance to redeem herself.

line1.text: She told us that Hagen was but a pawn, a mercenary hired by a man known as Hvedrung. He was the leader of the Boar Clan, which was native to Northgard.

line2.text: The mystery behind my tragedy grew, but one thing became clear: this "Hvedrung" was the mind commanding the hand... my father's true murderer.

Rescue.name: Intervention
Rescue.desc: The rebel faction of the Boar Clan faces extinction on a small island. Liv will help us repel the loyalists and save the rebel leader.

line0.desc: Reach ::value:: [Fame] to unleash the full potential of your [Mercenary]s.

line1.desc: Destroy the Boar loyalists' [TownHall].

line2.desc: Fulfill every one of Svarn's requests.

line3.desc: Reach ::value:: [Fame] before Year 4.

line4.desc: Win without building a [RavenPort].

line8.desc: Do not fail to meet Svarn's requests more than twice.

line0.text: Thanks to Liv, we learned that a small faction had split from the Boar Clan and that Hvedrung was trying to crush this uprising.

line1.text: If anyone could reveal Hvedrung's plans and weaknesses, it was the rebels' leader. I had to meet him.

line2.text: But first, we had to save our potential new ally, besieged by the loyalists. Liv would put her mercenary raids to good use. In a stroke of irony, our former enemy would save our future friend...

line0.text: This vendetta is none of our business, but if we join forces with the rebels, we may manage to defeat Hvedrung.

line1.text: I will assist you in this mission, my lord. I am nothing like Hagen, and I shall prove it to you.

line2.text: Freyja has finally answered our plea. I have... foreseen your coming.

line3.text: I... dreamt of a raven... swooping down on Hvedrung's face... pecking his eyes out.

line4.text: Svarn, your defiance is pointless. I have the horn now.

line5.text: I will quell your uprising, with or without their intervention. I too have foreseen the raven's coming, but in my dream, I crushed it in my fist.

line6.text: So, we finally meet, Hvedrung. I think you underestimate the toughness of this particular raven. It is two versus one now: your reign of terror is over.

line7.text: Reign of terror? Is that what you think this is? You have every reason to hate me, and I shall not deny my responsibility for your tragedy.

line8.text: Call me a villain if you like. Give in to rage if it numbs your pain.

line9.text: But this horn of yours has a higher purpose–one your simple mind could not fathom. One day you might understand. In a way, I do all of this for you.

line10.text: I... what? Do not try to present yourself in a favorable light, scum!

line11.text: Much is left to do. I shall take my leave now. I bid you farewell.

line12.text: NO! Come back here, you cowardly swine! Come and fight!

line13.text: My boy, I am not running away. I promise we will meet again and you shall have your revenge. When this day comes, I shall not duck away from it. Until then...

line14.text: Soldiers, I want Svarn's head. Put an end to this futile rebellion.

line15.text: I want that man DEAD! Liv, for now, our priority is to aid Svarn. Do not disappoint me.

line16.text: I am not worried in the least. My clan is well-versed in attacks from the sea. This island's terrain will give me an edge, and the enemy has their back to the water.

line17.text: My clan is master of the seas as well as trade. It is crucial that we build a harbor.

line18.text: We now have enough fame to upgrade our mercenary raids at the forge, but I don't think it will be enough to secure a victory. We should wait until we can unleash their full potential and target the enemy's town hall.

line19.text: We are starving... Winter might be our last... ordeal at this rate.

line20.text: Please, spare some food. We shall be... grateful.

line21.text: Hmm, winter looms ahead, indeed. A drain on my pantry will not make my job any easier.

line22.text: Moreover, I'm fairly certain this will not be the last of their requests.

line23.text: I understand this is quite a sacrifice, Liv, but if they starve to death, there will be no one left to rescue.

line24.text: Fair enough.

line25.text: I cannot... resist their attacks any longer... All is lost...

line26.text: I am sorry we failed you, Svarn. May you join Freyja in Fólkvang...

line27.text: Finally! Those tough devils have yielded.

line28.text: My... deepest thanks. We have lost many a good man, but they all... knew the risks they faced in... defying Hvedrung.

line29.text: I take no... joy in seeing his men die, though, for they too were once our brethren.

line30.text: I can only imagine how painful a civil war must be. Svarn, your brothers have not died in vain. Join me, and together we shall put an end to Hvedrung's plans.

line31.text: We will... gladly join your cause. There is much you have to... know about Hvedrung, and there might be yet more I need to learn...

line32.text: Svarn, we tried our best, but we cannot afford to spare supplies this time.

line33.text: I... do not doubt your good will. Thank you for trying... Worry not, for we can still resist on our own.

line34.text: Svarn... Once again, we are unable to provide supplies. Will you be able to hold on?

line35.text: Our situation is getting... grimmer by the day. To be frank, we are hanging by a thread.

line36.text: Liv, did you hear? I do not think there will be a third time. If we let Svarn down once more, he is done for!

line37.text: Yes, I heard. I am trying my best here.

line40.text: Will you be able to hold out?

line41.text: I... think so... Two towers still stand. We should be able to fend them off... for how long, I do not know.

line43.text: Hmm, things are starting to look grim.

line44.text: What can we do, apart from matching his requests?

line45.text: I am not sure... Maybe we should try to distract Hvedrung's forces?

line46.text: You're probably right. At any rate, Svarn will not be able to hold out for long. If they lose their last tower, they are done for.

line47.text: Now we're talking! Our mercenary raids can be fully upgraded. We will be able to harry the loyalists' shores efficiently!

line0.text: The Clan of Huginn and Muninn

line1.text: The Raven Clan can use their deep pockets filled with [Money]s to colonize new zones. They are the masters of trade and seldom lack riches.

line2.text: Their main asset is the ability to launch [Mercenary] Raids to harry their foes from the sea, while keeping out of reach from retaliation.

Giants.name: Jötunnheim
Giants.desc: We have to cross Jötunnheim, the land of giants, on our journey to the Runestone of Asgard. The Jötnar are a peaceful people. What could go wrong?

line0.desc: Destroy the enemy faction so your army can traverse the region.

line1.desc: Keep your Jötunn Champion alive at all costs.

line2.desc: Find a peaceful resolution to the conflict by revealing the Jötnar's ancient lore.

line3.desc: Supply [Food] to your [GiantFaction] allies through trade until they let you through.

line4.desc: Unravel the Jötnar's forgotten history by studying the giant sword.

line6.desc: Supply [Food] to your [GiantFaction] allies through trade until they let you through.

line0.text: With a serene face betraying no inner turmoil, Svarn, the rebel Boar leader, detailed Hvedrung's plan, although I could feel something boiling deep within him.

line1.text: The tyrant intended to destroy Bifrost, the legendary bridge to Asgard, for reasons unknown. But this would bring about Ragnarök, the end of the gods... and of our time. Svarn's rebellion existed solely to prevent this.

line2.text: Bifrost lay hidden, somewhere deep within Northgard. Svarn hoped to learn more by deciphering the gigantic Runestone of Asgard, an ancient frieze said to have been engraved by Odin himself.

line3.text: It was the beginning of a very long journey. And the first step was to cross a region called Jötunnheim: the land of giants.

line0.text: So, this is Jötunnheim. We have come across Jötnar in the past, so I am not too worried about crossing their homeland.

line1.text: No, Fjolsvin, it is OBVIOUS that all the sheep's wool and meat are rightfully ours. We own the animals and the grass they graze, so it is only fair we benefit from what they produce.

line2.text: You should be thankful: not only do we reward you for your measly labor, but we also defend you and the sheep from any danger!

line3.text: Reward?! My men are practically starving! You just sit all day, feasting off our "measly" labor!

line4.text: WE tend to the sheep, WE feed and clothe you, so WE should get to enjoy all of their products!

line5.text: Greetings, Jötnar. I am Rig, son of the late High King Hargurorf. We come in peace–we only ask that you let us pass, for we have vital business beyond the Jötunnheimar.

line6.text: SILENCE, HUMAN! I know nothing of you, nor do I care to.

line7.text: Wait, Skrymir, I have an idea. Why not ask the human who is in the right? This dispute has gone on long enough!

line8.text: I would rather not take sides. We just want through, really.

line9.text: We shall let you through once you pick a side.

line10.text: To me it is evident the owner of the sheep and the land should reap the benefits. It is theirs by right, without question.

line11.text: Those... are the words of a... spoiled child. Property is just one more way to... oppress the workers.

line12.text: I suggest they share both the work and the benefits. We simply have to establish a list of tasks and deadlines, and then divide the products equitably, notwithstanding the–

line13.text: Simpler solution: we cut all the sheep in half and split them fifty-fifty.

line14.text: I think the sheep's free will should also be taken into account. Perhaps THEY should choose where their products go.

line15.text: Wait, everyone! I must consider this.

line16.text: Should the wool and meat come down to us, we who work hard and protect and care for the sheep?

line17.text: ...Or to us, the rightful owners of the sheep and the land, which we inherited from our ancestors?

line18.text: And no, we won't share any longer. That would be betraying our forefathers' efforts.

line19.text: So... which will it be?

line20.text: I think Skrymir has a point. They own the sheep and the land, and they do reward and protect their workforce. Fjolsvin and his men are biting the hand that feeds them!

line21.text: I believe Fjolsvin is right: they may not OWN anything, but their hard work should entitle them to most of the benefits. Skrymir can make do with a fraction of the food.

line22.text: If you cannot work together and share both the labor and the benefits, then you are both of you fools. Again, I just want through, and I WILL have it my way.

line23.text: So you join the decadent oppressors! Brace for the righteous wrath of hard-working folk!

line24.text: That peasant Fjolsvin is responding with violence, what a surprise. Rid me of the ungrateful vermin.

line25.text: You can count on Lög, our Judicator, along with plenty of resources.

line26.text: Should our Champion fall, we won't stand a chance. Lög must be kept alive at all costs!

line27.text: So the humans join the ungrateful peasants! Brace for the wrath of the rightful lords of this region!

line28.text: That scum Skrymir responds with violence, as usual. We must overthrow his reign and build a brighter future.

line29.text: You can count on Jafnadr, Champion of the people, and a good amount of resources.

line30.text: Should our Champion fall, we won't stand a chance. Jafnadr must be kept alive at all costs!

line31.text: This looks... interesting. The giant sword... this... relic of the Jötnar could tell us more about their... history...

line32.text: Understood. Let us colonize the area and have our loremasters study it.

line33.text: Now, to study the old artifact...

line34.text: My lord... the giant Lög... Judicator of the land, has... fallen on the battlefield!

line35.text: Lög has yielded, at last! You do not stand a chance. Surrender, humans!

line36.text: My lord... the giant Jafnadr... Champion of the people, has... fallen on the battlefield!

line37.text: Jafnadr has yielded, at last! You do not stand a chance. Surrender, humans!

line39.text: And this, back here? Could it be...?

line40.text: Yes, yes... It all makes sense now... This is... the most exciting discovery!

line41.text: This is... or at least seems to be the sword of Bergelmir, one of only two survivors of the first generation of giants, and... ancestor to all living Jötnar.

line42.text: Yes, the sword represents the might of the rulers over the people. We protect them, and they work the land for us. The sword was placed here to split the population in two: the rulers and the peasants.

line43.text: We hate this relic. It represents oppression and division. It is a symbol of profound injustice. Bergelmir was most likely a tyrant.

line44.text: Well... obviously none of you bothered to... study the relic. Bergelmir placed his sword here to... resolve a dispute between his sons.

line45.text: The firstborn's birthright entitled him to Bergelmir's legacy, and the younger brother hated him for it.

line46.text: Bergelmir divided the land in two–the land you now call Jötunnheim. The sword was never intended as a symbol of division, but rather of sharing: the land... pain... joys. He wanted his sons to live AND work together.

line47.text: Perhaps I have been selfish. To be quite honest, I do feel guilty for not working all day. I hide behind the law, but in truth, I feel like an imposter.

line48.text: And you do protect and feed us. Maybe there is a world in which we can share the work and its fruits, as Bergelmir's sons eventually did?

line49.text: Thank you for showing us the truth, human. It was right in front of us all along, being in the middle of the land. You may pass now. We will make peace and work together.

line50.text: You made all that up, did you not?

line51.text: What do you think? It is just a big stone sword... with nothing written on it. Yet this small LIE shall beget a TRUTH of its own: a new world in which brothers are... united.

line52.text: What an uncomfortable piece of wisdom. Well, now we can resume our journey to the Runestone of Asgard. Well done, Svarn.

line53.text: There, Fjolsvin's rebellion has been crushed. I hope you are satisfied now, knowing you shall have to tend to the sheep and work the land yourselves.

line54.text: I, uhh... I confess I hadn't considered that. Ah, how hard can all that be, anyway? You may pass now–thank you for your help. You did the right thing.

line55.text: I am not... sure about this...

line56.text: There, Skrymir and his lords have been overthrown. I hope you are happy–you will have to defend yourselves now.

line57.text: Well, how hard can that be? Besides, it is better than being despoiled by lazy rulers.

line58.text: As the leader of a rebellion myself, I would find it hard to... disagree with you. Take care.

line59.text: I can't help thinking there could have been a less bloody alternative.

line60.text: You may be right, human. But it matters no longer. We bid you farewell now.

line61.text: You may be right, human. But it matters no longer. We bid you farewell now.

line64.text: Let us resume our journey to the Runestone of Asgard now, shall we?

line65.text: We've enough supplies to crush this uprising ourselves. Thank you for your support, humans. You were on the side of justice. Never doubt that.

line66.text: I still believe you could have worked this out peacefully with Fjolsvin, Skrymir. Will you let us through now?

line67.text: We Jötnar are always true to our word. You may pass. Fare thee well.

line68.text: We have enough supplies to overthrow their reign ourselves. Thank you for your support, humans. You were on the side of justice. Never doubt that.

line69.text: I still believe you could have worked this out peacefully with Fjolsvin, Skrymir. Will you let us through now?

line70.text: We Jötnar are always true to our word. You may pass. Fare thee well.

line71.text: My loremasters inform me they have made... great strides in understanding the secrets behind the giant relic.

line72.text: Excellent. I wonder what this will teach us.

line73.text: Human, I couldn't help but notice you've been trading lots of food with us lately.

line74.text: Human, I couldn't help but notice you've been trading lots of food with us lately.

line75.text: Indeed... Is this a bad thing?

line76.text: On the contrary. It gave me an idea. If you can supply more–much more, in fact–we should be able to fight Fjolsvin's forces on our own.

line77.text: On the contrary. It gave me an idea. If you can supply more–much more, in fact–we should be able to fight Skrymir's forces on our own.

line78.text: So, if we manage to provide enough food, you will let us through?

line79.text: Yes. You will not regret it, for we are by no means short on riches.

line80.text: Yes. You will not regret it, for we are by no means short on riches.

line81.text: We have traded ridiculous amounts of food with the Jötnar... We've nearly met our end of the bargain.

line82.text: Let us hope they will... keep theirs.

line0.text: The Clan of Slidrugtanni

line1.text: The Boar Clan is a wild people able to exploit the bounties of nature, but having less proficiency in trade and construction.

line2.text: They are also supremely erudite, so take advantage of their Menders to expand your [Lore] quickly.

Trials.name: Contest
Trials.desc: We are the first mainlanders to set foot in these regions. We will probably have to make our way through hostile wilds.

line0.desc: Win the contest by reaching ::value:: [Fame] before Borgild does.

line1.desc: Kill all the [Wyvern]s.

line2.desc: Colonize the [GiantFaction]s's camp.

line3.desc: Subdue Borgild by force.

line0.text: As we marched deeper into Northgard, Svarn wondered if the Regal Horn, the symbol of my royalty, could really be Gjallarhorn, Heimdall's famed instrument, said to herald Ragnarök.

line1.text: It would make sense; Hvedrung had killed my father and stolen my heirloom to end the world. My arch-nemesis gave me all the reasons in the world to hate him.

line2.text: Northgard had already thrown a great many trials at us since we first set foot here.

line3.text: But the one we would encounter next was not of these lands...

line0.text: I must say, I am proud we are the first people from the mainland to venture this far into Northgard.

line1.text: Actually... it would seem someone beat us to it...

line2.text: Greetings an' salutations! I'm Borgild of Bjarki, Clan of the Bear!

line3.text: Uhh... greetings? I am–

line4.text: You are me new servants, and you can start working the fields right now.

line5.text: Insolent woman! Do you not know who this man is?

line6.text: Apologies, milady, but do you realize to whom you are speaking?

line7.text: Uhh... don't you know this guy?

line8.text: ...Are you aware of whom you stand before?

line9.text: Evidently... you are not... familiar with your interlocutor.

line10.text: Oh, o' course I know him. He's Rig, son of the late High King Hargurorf. Do ye think me a peasant?

line11.text: Then you are aware he is your king and that–

line12.text: Oh, good. Then you very well know he is king and–

line13.text: Okay, you're no peasant. But this guy is our king, so...

line14.text: I would not dare call you this. But then, you are well aware he is king, and you are, ipso facto, his vassal.

line15.text: If you... know his lineage, you must understand... he is your king.

line16.text: King? What king? I see no Regal Horn. No Regal Horn, no high king. We both be from the mainland, both here to conquer Northgard. For all I know, I could be heir to the throne!

line17.text: You cannot be serious...

line18.text: Please do not go down this road...

line19.text: Ooh, I like her style!

line20.text: As a female leader, I salute your ambition... but this is nonsense!

line21.text: This... is quite unexpected. You have... gumption, she-bear! Nevertheless, you... cannot pretend to the throne...

line22.text: Brand, please. She is right, unfortunately. Without the horn, I am not officially high king.

line23.text: Halvard, I share your concerns. But as a leader, I cannot shy away from this trial.

line24.text: By Hel, she has guts, I give you that.

line25.text: Liv, she has a point. I am not my father–and alas, I no longer have the horn, so technically I cannot prove my birthright.

line26.text: Svarn, I am afraid she may be right–I am not officially the high king. Perhaps it is my fate to prove it.

line27.text: Borgild, what would it take for you to accept me as your rightful sovereign?

line28.text: Well... I say we engage in a contest. The clan that accomplishes the most epic deeds will be deemed victor and crowned high king. Well, high queen, most likely.

line29.text: The loser, on the other hand... must bend the knee and satisfy the winner's every whim.

line30.text: Epic deeds? When it comes to fame, you are on shaky ground with me! Lord Rig, let us put her to shame!

line31.text: That is ludicrous and unreasonable. Surely Lord Rig will not stoop to–

line32.text: Ooh, say yes! Say yes!

line33.text: Fighting over fame is both childish and futile. Lord Rig will never–

line34.text: Pursuing fame is without merit... I do not... believe Lord Rig will–

line35.text: Agreed. I accept the challenge, Borgild.

line36.text: What do you think? Of course I accept the challenge!

line38.text: Excellent! I must admit, I was initially against this idea... but now I say make her pay for her hubris!

line39.text: There, I knew the young lord would do the sensible thing.

line40.text: Wait, what? Young lord, I beg you to reconsider. You've nothing to prove–you are the legitimate ruler of the clans!

line41.text: YAAAH! Fame means killing deadly things! I can't wait!

line42.text: I cannot wait to waste resources just for show. Yay!

line43.text: Hmm... This is... interesting. I did not... foresee this outcome.

line44.text: I am glad to hear this. Your resources and skalds will be put to good use. May this contest go down in history!

line45.text: You may be right, Halvard, but I see no way around this trial. She will not let us through, and we cannot afford to antagonize her.

line46.text: Your strength and bravery will be precious assets, Egil. Let us show her how her might pales in comparison to ours!

line47.text: Sarcasm noted. But my mind is made up. I will need all your wits for this. We WILL force Borgild into submission!

line48.text: I understand you do not approve of my choice, but believe me, there much to be learned from this. We will emerge victorious.

line49.text: Ha! Ye've got more nerve than I anticipated. 'Twill be interesting, for sure. Good luck to ya, hornless king! You'll be needin' it.

line50.text: Is it me or is it gettin' cold? Oh yes, winter is comin'! I guess you be planning on spending the cold season by the hearth, eatin' hot soup...

line51.text: But we won't. My clan THRIVES in winter. We won't be idlin' around, and neither should ye.

line52.text: This will not make our task any easier. She is right–we can't afford to hibernate, or we will fall behind.

line53.text: A wyvern! My father used to boast of fighting one during his travels, but I never really believed it was real!

line54.text: Slaying such a fiend would be worthy of a skald's song. It will not go down easily, though, so make sure you send enough warriors.

line55.text: 'Tis the most terrifying thing I have seen in my days. And believe me, young lord, I have witnessed a great deal. Many men and women will likely die fighting this beast, if you so command it.

line56.text: By Fenrir, I'm shaking with excitement! How hard can it be to kill? Let's find out! I've got a spot for its head above my fireplace!

line57.text: That looks... dangerous. I can see why we would risk our lives fighting it, but is it really worth it?

line58.text: Wyverns are... mighty foes. We usually respect them and leave them be, although killing it would surely impress the she-bear.

line59.text: It certainly won't go down without a fight. Warriors, brace yourselves!

line60.text: Another wyvern! Hmm, this one looks less intimidating than what we encountered earlier. It should be easier to defeat.

line61.text: Indeed. We would lose fewer men and women than against the bigger one.

line62.text: It still looks like a formidable opponent. We should not underestimate it.

line63.text: Yeah, but it's less fun, too. The bigger bugger was more... bitey.

line64.text: It still looks pretty nasty. But if we REALLY must slay things to show off, it might be a better choice than the huge, nightmare-fueling one.

line65.text: It is indeed less dangerous than the bigger variety... but make no mistake, it is still a very tough creature.

line66.text: By Odin's missing eye! Is this a wyvern? My father boasted of fighting one, but this thing is bigger than a longship!

line67.text: It looks fearsome, indeed. We certainly should not expect this battle to be easily won, if winnable at all.

line68.text: Attacking such a beast would be madness, young lord! I beg you not to give in to hubris. My people are tough survivors, but ordering them to face this monster would be tantamount to murder.

line69.text: Whoa, I might actually be experiencing fear for the first time ever. Nah, just kidding. I'm not sure my axes can even put a dent in its scales, though. Only one way to find out!

line70.text: Well, this is absurd. Throwing warriors at this creature would be a needless waste of human life. On the other hand–and I can hardly believe I'm considering it–slaying it would give us a definite edge in the contest...

line71.text: I have seen wyverns, but never this big. I foresee many lives being wiped out if you decide to fight it, although... it would most certainly be the stuff of legends.

line72.text: Agreed. At any rate, it would require more than a few warriors to bring it down. I will have to carefully consider this.

line73.text: You may just be right, Halvard. Yet somehow I feel we are up to the task... if we prepare carefully beforehand, that is.

line74.text: I know your warriors are ready to die just for a chance to fight such a unique beast. We will probably have to send in quite a few of them, though.

line75.text: 'Tis quite a gamble, indeed. We stand to lose many in the fight, but should we succeed... At any rate, we shall have to plan ahead carefully.

line76.text: Many lives would be lost, 'tis true. On the other hand, if Borgild's people manage to bring it down, we might be done for. I will have to think it over.

line77.text: Another wyvern! Hmm, this one is a good deal bigger than the one we saw earlier. It is bound to make more damage.

line78.text: It does look mightier. We should not take this beast lightly. In all likelihood, we shall have to draw even more warriors into the fight.

line79.text: The "small" one looked bad enough. I dread to imagine what will happen if we disturb this one's slumber.

line80.text: Yeah, it looks bigger and badder. I wonder if my axes can even make a dent in its scales. Let's find out!

line81.text: From a purely rational point of view, it represents even more risk, but for a similar reward. Of course, not killing it would be a missed opportunity entirely. But is it worth the extra danger?

line82.text: The lesser wyverns are certainly mighty beasts, but they are nothing compared to the greater variety.

line84.text: Either befriending them through trade or slaying them and claiming their land would increase our fame. This is essentially an ethical dilemma, so please do as you see fit, my lord.

line85.text: If we trade food with them, they become our allies and we gain fame. Of course, we could also slay them and claim their land, but is peace not preferable to war?

line86.text: I say we slay 'em and take their land! That oughta show Borgild what we're made of! Sure, we could trade food with them and make them our allies... but that'd be boring.

line87.text: There are two ways we could gain fame from them: either defeat them and claim their land, or trade food with them until we've befriended them. Both are economically viable options. Decisions, decisions...

line88.text: We can either... collaborate with them through trade or... eradicate them and claim their land. Jotnär are powerful allies, but it will be costly. On the other hand, they are mighty foes...

line89.text: Earning their trust would take a while and cost a lot of food, but we would gain a powerful ally to accomplish other glorious deeds. Slaying them would be swifter but more dangerous and less rewarding. I need to ponder both options.

line90.text: 'Tis over, Borgild. Admit it: I beat you at your own game.

line92.text: Ha! Our victory has rendered her speechless! Do you see how futile your efforts have been, woman?

line93.text: So, milady, will you finally listen to reason and kneel before Lord Rig?

line94.text: What's wrong? That little game of yours not so fun anymore?

line95.text: So, will you at last cut your losses and stop this tired nonsense?

line96.text: You have been... bested, she-bear. Do you now... see what I see in Lord Rig?

line97.text: All right. I can't weasel out of this. Ye brought me down a peg or two, hornless king.

line98.text: That is the spirit! Do you then recognize me as your rightful king and swear allegiance to me?

line99.text: As per the rules o' the contest, I'll submit to ya. But make no mistake: until you show me the Regal Horn, I'll NEVER accept you as my king!

line100.text: Fine by me. I am sure I will have use for your skills in the days ahead. Let us not tarry.

line101.text: Borgild, all things considered, I have decided to put an end to this. Submit now. That is not a request.

line102.text: Wait, that's not how it's meant to be! Ye must respect the rules of the contest!

line103.text: It seems Lord Rig has grown impatient, though I'll concede that winning this way is not very honorable.

line104.text: Apologies, milady, but there are more important matters at hand. Let us avoid shedding any more blood: please yield peacefully.

line105.text: You fought well–we're just better than you. Way better, ha ha!

line106.text: Only the outcome matters. Now, surrender without making a fuss–do not give the men that satisfaction. I promise you will not regret joining us. Just swallow your pride for now.

line107.text: I... understand your anger, but please heed our words. There is... so much more at stake than just honor.

line108.text: That's unfair! Rig, you despicable dog, do ye have no sense of honor? Aren't you supposed to be high king?

line109.text: Ha ha! King? What king? I see no Regal Horn. No Regal Horn, no high king. Remember?

line110.text: What is your agenda? What're you after? Some kind o'... sense of achievement?

line111.text: Maybe so. Anyway, do you agree to swear allegiance to me now?

line112.text: Grr... I'll never accept you as my king, but you've made your point. I concede!

line113.text: Well, well, well... Looks like the mighty "high king" ain't so mighty after all. So, about this "satisfying the victor's every whim" deal...

line114.text: My lord, I am ashamed to have failed you. She has won, and so we must surrender honorably.

line115.text: What did I tell you, young lord? How could you put this venture in jeopardy just for show? All is lost now...

line116.text: What do ya know! Looks like we have a new queen. Hey, Borg, if you need a king by your side, I'm all yours! Ow-hoooo!

line117.text: Ah, well, it seems I have yet a new master. But I shall be glad to serve under a woman this time! Hail to the high queen!

line118.text: This... this cannot be happening! None will be able to stop Hvedrung now! Lord Rig, you have FAILED your people and the gods!

line120.text: Lady Borgild, I concede and pledge my allegiance to you...

line121.text: You're falling behind, hornless king! You did understand the rules of the contest, right?

line122.text: I am just giving you a headstart, usurper!

line123.text: Hey, Borgild, it looks as though you're falling behind.

line124.text: Yeah, keep talking... I'm just giving you a headstart!

line125.text: Hey, mighty "high king", you're obviously no good at this, so let me give you a tip: do what I'm doing–that's how I got ahead of you.

line126.text: Sheesh! Will this woman ever shut up?

line127.text: Slow and steady wins the race, milady.

line128.text: This chick's as cocky as she is ruthless. I think I'm in love.

line129.text: Trash talking is vulgar and pointless.

line131.text: Fame... is like a flower. Yours is... blooming today, but it shall be wilting tomorrow...

line132.text: Let us not be distracted by her taunts. Though I must admit she is irksome.

line133.text: Usurper, you're evidently not so skilled at this, so here is a friendly tip: just do what I am doing–that is how I got ahead of you.

line135.text: I suppose a bit of taunting cannot hurt.

line136.text: Booyah! Hear that, Borg? Or are you too far behind?

line138.text: Oh... that was actually... quite humorous. Ho ho ho.

line140.text: Well, it looks like I'm going to win. If you're all right with it, I'll take some time to make a list of errands for you once you're my thrall.

line141.text: Do not get ahead of yourself, usurper! 'Tis not over till it's over!

line142.text: So, usurper, do you recognize me as your high king?

line143.text: Why should I? Last I checked, you hadn't proven your worth.

line144.text: I was merely warming up. Obviously I will win at this rate.

line146.text: Looks like the contest is coming to a close...

line0.text: The Contest

line1.text: To prove your worth to Borgild and make her recognize you as high king, you must raise your [Fame]. Do so faster than she does.

line2.text: Many feats will bring you fame: claiming camps, slaying colossal creatures, and of course developing your clan.

Guardian.name: Tremors
Guardian.desc: The Runestone of Asgard is at last within reach, in a desolate, rime-covered steppe. We need only walk there!

line0.desc: Reach the Runestone of Asgard and decipher its runes.

line1.desc: Build the [Forge].

line2.desc: Mine [RimeSteel].

line3.desc: Forge the Wurmslayer.

line4.desc: Bring the Hrímgandr down using the Wurmslayer.

line6.desc: Have ::value:: different types of military units at any one time.

line7.desc: Exploit ::value:: Rimesteel mines at any one time.

line0.text: I had just managed to subdue Borgild and her Bear Clan on our way to the Runestone. They were, like us, from the old continent, but had come ashore in a completely different place.

line1.text: As we neared the Runestone, Svarn grew more and more agitated. He confessed to be dreading "something" that lay ahead, though he couldn't tell what it was.

line2.text: Some of our people were also reluctant to move forward; Northgard was getting harsher and harsher, as if trying to deter us from pursuing our goal...

line0.text: Hmm, the air is g-getting colder. Much c-colder, as a matter of f-fact.

line1.text: That is one w-way to put it... I am f-f-freezing!

line2.text: Yeah, I'm kind of regretting all my l-life choices, being a b-b-berserker and all. I c-can't feel my t-toes...

line3.text: I j-just long for a hot s-soup b-by the hearth...

line4.text: I am thinking of all the f-firewood we'll have to b-burn to get warm again, and it is making me d-depressed...

line5.text: Come, now! A little cold air never killed no one! Are ye all babies? Want me to tuck ye in warm little beddies?

line6.text: Hey, I'm all f-for you warming up my b-bed...

line7.text: Really, Egil...

line8.text: Let's just say ye're not me type, doggy boy...

line9.text: Lo! We have arrived... the R-Runestone of A-Asgard lies yonder! Let us hie there!

line10.text: S-Svarn?

line11.text: We should... turn back. I... do not wish... to FACE what lies ahead!

line12.text: Come on, piggy, it's just a big stone. Ye boars aren't afraid of rocks now, are ye?

line13.text: Whoa! What was that?

line14.text: NO! NOT... THIS! THIS BEAST HAS... HAUNTED MY DREAMS ALL MY LIFE!

line15.text: Ooooh! 'Tis a Hrímgandr! I never saw one with me own two eyes. All me ancestors famously killed one each!

line16.text: You th-think you c-can s-slay that b-beast, B-Borgild?

line17.text: Well, I can't pass up the chance to hang its head in my trophy room. Even if I die tryin'. Let's settle here.

line18.text: Ahh, 'tis good to feel my fingers again. So, how should we go about slaying the beast?

line19.text: Those beasties are pretty much invulnerable to basic weapons. We have to forge a special family weapon we call the Wurmslayer. We'll need some rimesteel and a forge.

line20.text: RIMESTEEL? The famous icy ore said to be found only in Niflheim?!

line21.text: Ye southerners sure know how to inflate yer legends. No need to go to Niflheim: Hrímgandar typically live in rimesteel-rich environments, so we shouldn't have too much trouble finding some 'round here.

line22.text: Weeeelll... good luck with that.

line23.text: Borgild, I will help you fend off the beast while the miners are at work. Even if we cannot make a dent in its armor for the time being, we should be able to distract it, no?

line24.text: Clearly I cannot watch this from the sidelines... I shall help too, Lady Borgild!

line25.text: Can't let a chick take all the credit for downing such a big monster now, can I? Count me in, Borg!

line26.text: Not too keen on being devoured alive, but... we haven't much of a choice, it would appear. Count me in, too!

line27.text: I need to face my DEEPEST fears... I shall fight with you all!

line28.text: All right, let's do this!

line29.text: We have enough rimesteel to start forging the Wurmslayer!

line30.text: So... what are ye waitin' for? Build a forge already!

line31.text: The Wurmslayer's blade has been forged!

line32.text: The Wurmslayer's crossguard has been forged!

line33.text: The Wurmslayer is complete!

line34.text: Och! 'Twas about time! Now I get to live up to my family's tradition of slaying Hrímgandar!

line36.text: This ought to make us famous, for sure.

line37.text: I cannot lie, I am indeed a tad excited. But mostly terrified.

line38.text: Exciting, indeed. I cannot wait to be chewed alive.

line40.text: Ooh, is it me or is this winter cooler than the last one?

line41.text: Hmm, winters are getting colder and colder... I don't mind, but maybe we should hurry just a little. Hrímgandar love cold winters even more than I do.

line42.text: Okay, it's getting seriously cold now, even for me. If it keeps getting worse, the Hrímgandr will become invincible for good.

line43.text: Th-this is b-bad... Even I am f-freezing... At th-this r-rate, n-next w-winter will b-be our last...

line44.text: 'T-tis m-mighty c-cold... Th-there's no w-way w-we can k-kill the b-beastie now...

line45.text: D-darn, we have to b-back down...

line46.text: Th-then it m-means th-that nothing will stand in Hvedrung's w-way now... All is l-lost...

line48.text: See, piggy? The beastie's dead. I think I'll need a bigger fireplace, though. 'Tis a big one.

line49.text: Strange... The air suddenly became slightly warmer...

line50.text: Me ancestors used to say killing a Hrímgandr could hasten spring. Maybe that's why winters were getting harsher in the area?

line51.text: Svarn, the only thing left to do is decipher the Runestone of Asgard...
