line52.text: Yes... Let us... see what TRUTH the runes have to tell us...

line53.text: Companions, I must withdraw for now. I shall return once I am back on my feet. Stay brave!

line54.text: I am not as hale as I once was... I must catch my breath and get these wounds taken care of... But I will return once I have recovered!

line55.text: Darn, that thing packs quite a punch... Hate to say it, but I need to back down for now. I'll come back soon as I get these wounds patched up!

line56.text: Ouch! Sorry, all, I have to back down for now... I will come back once my wounds have healed. Stay strong!

line57.text: I am... heavily wounded. Sorry, companions, but I must... withdraw for now. I shall return as soon as I have... healed.

line58.text: What the...?! The Hrímgandr just devoured a rimesteel deposit!

line59.text: Aye, Hrímgandar feed on rimesteel. That's why they live close to deposits.

line60.text: I suppose we shouldn't let it get too comfortable, then. It has probably been idle for too long. If we let it eat all the rimesteel, we'll be left with no way to slay it.

line61.text: My prospectors just reported there wasn't enough rimesteel left in those plains to forge a Wurmslayer... It's hopeless.

line62.text: Hmm, there has to be a way... Could we wait for it to die of old age?

line63.text: Hah... Do ye have a thousand years to spare? It's hopeless, I tell ya!

line64.text: Good, 'tis the first territory with rimesteel we control... We'd best defend it, 'cause the beastie don't like trespassers!

line0.text: The Clan of Bjarki

line1.text: This clan is less susceptible to the effects of winter and cold than others, and is even more powerful and productive during that season!

line2.text: Their mastery of shields and ability to train armored bears make them experts in the art of defense.

line0.text: We had finally reached the Runestone of Asgard. Whoever Hvedrung was, his actions seemed to be foretold by the old scriptures etched in the stone.

line1.text: Svarn translated: "He will want to set the men free from the yoke of the All-Father, for he does not want them to share in his feast, and to this end he will destroy Bifrost."

line2.text: "As the wail of Gjallarhorn echoes through the skies, the sons of Muspell will march on Asgard. Thus the gods shall meet their fate, and the age of men shall begin," Svarn concluded thoughtfully.

line3.text: There was no map to Bifrost on the Runestone, but one stanza read that it was "beyond Bergelmir's Throat." This was a kenning (a metaphor) for the icy cliffs far to the north.

Frozen.name: Fimbulvinter
Frozen.desc: We have reached Bergelmir's Throat, the narrow pass opening on Bifröst. Winter seems to know no end here.

line0.desc: Wait for Fimbulvinter to end (::value:: years).

line1.desc: Survive the frozen army of the dead.

line2.desc: Build at least ::value:: upgraded [WatchTower]s.

line3.desc: Survive without building a [WatchTower].

line4.desc: Do not allow any of your allies to fall.

line0.text: As we neared Bergelmir's Throat, we were greeted by an eternal winter; Borgild called it Fimbulvinter, and that alone was one of our mightiest foes yet.

line1.text: But as the Norns would have it, something much deadlier than cold and starvation was lurking in the freezing mist...

line0.text: You said it was getting warmer, Halvard?

line1.text: I stand corrected.

line2.text: Good thing we have better clothes now!

line3.text: S-speak f-for yours-self, g-golden b-boy...

line4.text: This be Fimbulvinter.

line5.text: Fimbul-what now?

line6.text: The eternal winter, luv.

line7.text: On the bright side, those undead freaks will stay frozen forever.

line8.text: The downside is, we'll never get past this here wall of ice.

line9.text: Which means we are never going to get past this here wall of ice...

line10.text: So, what now...? Is this the end of the road?

line11.text: No... "Eternal" is a... poetic license, not to be taken literally. Fimbulvinter is an extremely HARSH and long winter that is supposed to last several years.

line12.text: The legends say it is a... harbinger of Ragnarök. If they are to be believed, Hvedrung might be... close to achieving his goal.

line13.text: Then we "only" have to wait for the return of spring?

line14.text: What concerns me slightly is what will happen when the wretched creatures thaw out...

line15.text: Then we may not look forward to spring, after all... Lo!

line16.text: The blizzard has lifted... What are those wretched figures?

line17.text: Hmm, good point.

line18.text: A frightful sight, indeed... Luckily, they are frozen solid. But you are right, Halvard: if the wall is bound to thaw, so are they!

line19.text: What a peculiar feeling. We usually dread the coming of winter, not its end!

line20.text: Bergelmir's Throat is a funnel-shaped gorge, and we are on its broad end. I suggest we spread out our settlements to weaken the impact of the attack.

line21.text: A reasonable solution. That way, no one will bear the full brunt of the assault.

line22.text: Brand and I will be defending the middle.

line23.text: Halvard and I will be defending the middle.

line24.text: Egil and I will be defending the middle.

line25.text: Liv and I will be defending the middle.

line26.text: Svarn and I will be defending the middle.

line27.text: Borgild and I will be defending the middle.

line28.text: Brand will protect our right flank...

line29.text: Halvard will protect our right flank...

line30.text: Egil will protect our right flank...

line31.text: Liv will protect our right flank...

line32.text: Svarn will protect our right flank...

line33.text: Borgild will protect our right flank...

line34.text: ... and Brand the left one.

line46.text: Then it is settled. Let us gather as many resources as we can and prepare to resist the charge when Fimbulvinter ends.

line47.text: The first year has flown by. We have three more years before the end of Fimbulvinter. The air is already warming.

line48.text: Only two years left before the thaw. Now is no time to rest!

line49.text: Another year has passed... Fimbulvinter should end next year, if the legends are true. We ought to work twice as hard!

line51.text: My lord, the remainder of the army is thawing out!

line52.text: By Odin's eye... The frozen army is bound to descend on us!

line53.text: Ah... It's warmin' up finally... Freaks incoming! Get ready to fight!

line54.text: The army of the dead is thawing out...

line56.text: 'Tis warmer, all right! The freaks be incoming!

line57.text: Brace yourselves for battle! This is the final assault... We will hold our ground... or die trying!

line58.text: My lord, the eastern front has fallen! We must prepare for an attack on our right flank!

line59.text: Young lord, I fear our friends on the eastern front have fallen! We should brace for an attack from the right!

line60.text: Those guys on the right side didn't make it. Just means more monsters for me to fight! Sweet!

line61.text: Blast, the eastern front has failed to hold their position. Our right side is now exposed.

line62.text: Our friends on the... eastern front have fallen. We MUST be prepared to deal with their attackers.

line63.text: Och, those weaklings on the eastern side didn't make it! Prepare to be attacked from the right!

line64.text: My lord, the western front has fallen! Our left flank is bound to be harried soon!

line65.text: Young lord, our friends on the western front did all they could, but they have been overwhelmed. We are bound to be attacked from the left!

line66.text: And there goes the left side! I get their share of the freaks to battle! Nice!

line67.text: Bad news... The western front is no more. Our left side is now vulnerable.

line68.text: Our allies on the... western front are no more. We must BRACE for an attack from the left.

line69.text: Ye got to be kidding me. The men to the west had ONE job! If they've failed, we'll be attacked from the left soon.

line70.text: Phew, that was not an easy battle. Salvage whatever is left and heal the wounded.

line71.text: Lo! The wall of ice is melting!

line72.text: It's about time! Let's get out of here before I cool down.

line73.text: At last! I just hope what lies beyond is not even colder.

line74.text: Even I am fed up with all that snow. Think I've got rime in me boots.

line75.text: I fear the worst is yet to come.

line76.text: Indeed... Beyond Bergelmir's Throat is Bifröst... and Hvedrung. We must STOP this madman.

line77.text: We must carry on. Whatever is next will be the end of our quest. We are nearing the northern borders of Northgard.

line78.text: Let us march on! TO BIFROST!

line79.text: I can only promise you more blood and tears. But our fate, and that of Northgard–perhaps all of humanity–will soon be sealed.

line0.text: Fimbulvinter

line1.text: The Great Winter will last several years. Wait for spring to melt the great ice wall.

line2.text: Brace yourself for when the army of the dead will thaw out. Protect your allies, for you are stronger together!

Bifrost.name: Bifröst
Bifrost.desc: Bifröst, the legendary bridge leading to Asgard, sits in this region. Hvedrung is already there, and we are on the brink of Ragnarök. We must stop him at all costs!

line0.desc: Protect [Bifrost] at all costs.

line1.desc: Slay Hvedrung.

line2.desc: Seal one [Muspell] each year.

line3.desc: Annihilate all the poor [KoboldFaction]s.

line4.desc: Do not let [Bifrost] fall below 50% durability.

line0.text: At last we were reaching our goal. The land where Bifrost had been concealed for eons was... peaceful. Heavenly, even.

line1.text: But as we marched forward, a great indescribable sound shook earth and sky alike. It still echoes through my mind.

line2.text: This was, of course, Gjallarhorn's wail, and the beginning of Ragnarök.

line3.text: Hvedrung was ahead of us, ready to set the sons of Muspell loose on Northgard.

line4.text: Everything we had done to get here, every life sacrificed, would have been in vain if we failed to stop the tyrant from destroying the legendary bridge.

line0.text: Bifröst, at last!

line1.text: What a dreadful sound!

line2.text: Hvedrung has blown Gjallarhorn... Thus, we are on the brink of Ragnarök. The sons of Muspell shall be here soon.

line3.text: Hvedrung, stop this folly at once!

line4.text: I salute your determination, young king. But you are too late: with Gjallarhorn, I will open the gates of Muspelheim.

line5.text: This world shall soon be engulfed in flames... but believe me, 'tis no folly.

line6.text: But why...? What have you to gain from all this? And how did the Runestone of Asgard foretell your baleful deeds? Who ARE you?

line7.text: Who I am is unimportant, as were your father and your pathetic quest for revenge. All that matters is what will be gained from destroying Bifröst.

line8.text: You are a madman! What do you want? To slay the gods? To become the absolute ruler of Asgard?

line9.text: I do not seek to rule over gods or men. I wish to set Midgard and Asgard asunder, to set men free from Odin's will.

line10.text: That is nonsense! What would humans have to gain from losing the All-Father? What good would a world of ashes be to us?

line11.text: Odin lives in perpetual dread of Ragnarök, for he knows he shall meet his fate. He has been training our brethren in Valhöll in hopes of preventing his inevitable demise.

line12.text: He has no love for humans. To him they are mere puppets, whom he has been stringing along with empty promises of eternal glory since the dawn of time.

line13.text: Do not listen to him, my lord... Hvedrung is a heretic. His words have poisoned many of my brothers' souls...

line14.text: There is no... reasoning with him. The very existence of my... rebellion proves he will only respond to... force.

line15.text: You are wiser than I am, Svarn. You always have been. But your faith is misguided. Fight the inevitable if you so desire.

line16.text: Now, let Ragnarök... COMMENCE!

line17.text: Fire giants incoming!

line18.text: Young lord, the final battle is nigh! You can count on us and the settlements we built all over Northgard to send you support!

line19.text: My lord, the final battle is nigh! You can count on us and the settlements we built all over Northgard to send you support!

line20.text: Bifröst is under attack too! We must send troops to defend it!

line21.text: Huh? The fire giants died suddenly! What is happening?

line22.text: It seems the Eldthursar are unable to sustain their presence far from the flames of Muspelheim. This will work in our favor, but we cannot leave Bifröst unattended.

line23.text: We must hie to any gate we can find, and then seal them!

line24.text: Is that... Vedrfolnir?

line25.text: Its senses must have been disrupted by Gjallarhorn. The poor thing has crashed to the ground.

line26.text: I know I am asking much of you all. Everything we have done–every life taken, every life lost–has led us to this point.

line27.text: We must protect Bifröst at all costs! We cannot allow Ragnarök to happen! Hvedrung dies this day!

line28.text: My lord, we have just received a shipment of supplies and reinforcements from our Northgard allies.

line29.text: Young lord, we have received help and supplies from our Northgardian fellows!

line30.text: Hey, Rig, we just got more guys and supplies from all over Northgard!

line31.text: I've been informed that our settlements all across Northgard have sent help and supplies.

line32.text: Our Northgardian... brethren have sent us men and a shipment of supplies!

line33.text: Hey, hornless king, we just received blokes and a bunch of supplies from the rest of Northgard!

line34.text: At long last! I have finally cornered you.

line36.text: Hvedrung, you have... lost. Ragnarök has not... come to pass. Everything you did was in vain.

line38.text: Look, the coward surrenders! Kill him anyway!

line39.text: What do you have to say for yourself, fiend?

line41.text: So much suffering... and for what?

line42.text: Well, clearly he has nothing to say in his own defense.

line43.text: Your revenge is at hand, my lord.

line44.text: You must be truly mad. Faced with your own demise, you dare laugh at my face? I will put you out of your misery.

line46.text: ... But you still arrived too late.

line47.text: Finally... the sons of Muspell have destroyed Bifröst...

line48.text: Odin, prepare to meet your fate!

line50.text: There, all the gates have been sealed. We can call back the other bannermen, as we no longer need them as backup.

line0.text: The Sons of Muspell

line1.text: Fire giants will pour from the gates of Muspell. Fend them off while trying to seal as many gates as possible to reduce their inflow.

line2.text: Protect Bifröst at all costs, survive the assault by Hvedrung's lieutenants, and put an end to his folly when the time comes!

line0.text: Hvedrung was finally in my grasp. He had failed and we were the victors. Or so I thought.

line1.text: Just as I was about to end his miserable life, Hvedrung smiled peacefully, betraying no hint of regret or bitterness.

line2.text: "You are victorious, High King," he said, "but you still arrived too late. Bifrost may still stand, yet the World Tree has been shaken to its roots. You think you prevented Ragnarök; I say we are in the midst of it."

line3.text: He went on: "My work here is done; the men may not yet be free from Odin's yoke, but they now know that defiance is an option. This is the dawn of a new era. Do what you will with me, spare me or kill me; it matters not."

line4.text: Why those words pierced my soul, I shall never know. I suddenly lost all will to kill him, realizing how futile it would be. It would never bring my father back, and he was right; Ragnarök WAS happening.

line5.text: Or rather... it IS happening. This is a new era indeed. Our story is not over; it is only beginning. Northgard needs to heal, and we will be here to tend to its wounds.

line6.text: So, this continent we once called untamed and hostile... We shall now call it...

line7.text: Home.

line0.text: Ragnarök has only just begun.

line0.desc: Colonize the Portal to Yggdrazil and keep controle during one year

line1.desc: Kill at least 20 Valkyries

line2.desc: Reach 10 happiness and keep that during one year

line3.desc: Reach Portal before year 4

line0.text: At last we were reaching our goal. But as we marched forward, a great indescribable sound shook earth and sky alike. It still echoes through my mind.

line1.text: This was, of course, Gjallarhorn's wail, and the beginning of Ragnarök. It had opened the portal to Bifrost, and in so doing had upset the world itself.

line2.text: Hurrying across a Northgard that was more wretched than ever, we made our way to the portal to thwart Hvedrung's baleful plans.

line0.desc: Test objectif 1

line1.desc: Test objectif 2 : ::value::

line0.desc: Bla bla bla

line0.text: The events I am about to recount are the ones that precede and follow Northgard's desertion.

line1.text: I am not the hero of this story, but I will be the one to tell it.

line2.text: For it marked the end of an era, and that era was mine.

Hvergelmir.name: Hvergelmir
Hvergelmir.desc: Rig summons all of his remaining allies, hoping to put an end to Ragnarök.

line0.desc: Capture Hvedrung and convince him to help.

line1.desc: Reach Bifröst and summon the Aesir.

line2.desc: Seal every Gate of Muspell.

line3.desc: Capture Hvedrung in less than 3 years.

line0.text: The fight against Hvedrung had brought the six clans of Northgard together in a strong alliance.

line1.text: But it did not suffice to prevent the onset of Ragnarök.

line2.text: Following the fateful day that Bifröst was damaged, an eternal night shrouded our land and many gates of fire and stone opened up all over Northgard.

line3.text: Through these doors, the sons of Muspell continued their assault across Northgard. We were forced to split up in order to repel them.

line4.text: In the midst of this ordeal, the separation of our clans was the danger I dreaded most.

line5.text: Faith in a king who failed to preserve Northgard was wavering. With no more hope to spare, our alliance had become fragile.

line6.text: I had to reunite the clans if I wanted this kingdom to survive.

line0.text: It is good to see you here, Liv! Thank you for answering the call.

line1.text: This place brings back memories.

line2.text: We had not reunited all the clans since...

line3.text: ... since our sham victory!

line4.text: And we've endured more hardships after that day than Ymir did when his blood filled the seas.

line5.text: What a journey, my friends!

line6.text: Svarn! Do you happen to know how Halvard is getting by?

line7.text: My king, I'm afraid Halvard has left Northgard quite a while ago.

line8.text: Come again?

line9.text: A life of endless combat against the sons of Muspell ran counter to Halvard’s ideals. The clan of the goat returned to its homeland.

line10.text: How cowardly!

line11.text: Egil! You made it too!

line12.text: Don't tell me you doubted it! Where's Brand?

line13.text: Brand never forgave me for sparing Hvedrung's life. We had a violent strife. He left Northgard.

line14.text: Did you summon us here to share all these rejoicing news?

line15.text: I have asked you to come because I want these disasters to stop.

line16.text: I plan to put an end to Ragnarök, but I will need your help for that.

line17.text: What's your plan?

line18.text: We need to capture Hvedrung again.

line19.text: What good would he do? He is the one who started it all!

line20.text: Precisely. And he is the one who knows Bifröst best.

line21.text: How will that help us?

line22.text: I want to summon the Aesir and ask for their help. I want them to ride across Bifröst and descend upon Northgard.

line23.text: Splendid!

line24.text: If we catch Hvedrung again, this time, I want to kill him.

line25.text: We just have to keep him alive until he's outrun his usefulness.

line26.text: If that's what it takes to get through this...

line27.text: Then it is settled. He gathered his last followers in a small settlement north of here. Let us get to him!

line28.text: What a surprise. Weren't you all busy fighting the Eldthursar?

line29.text: We don't appreciate your sarcasm.

line30.text: Give it up! We just want to talk.

line31.text: Oh, sure. And I'm the mother of Odin's eight-legged horse!

line32.text: Why now? Nothing has changed since you decided to spare my life.

line33.text: We’re not reversing this decision yet. Just come with us and nothing will happen to you.

line34.text: Who do you think you are?

line35.text: ... What do you want with me?

line36.text: We want you to put an end to Ragnarök.

line37.text: You’re still the same naïve simpleton, Svarn...

line38.text: We need the Aesir to descend upon Midgard. I know you can summon them!

line39.text: ... Would you trust me with Gjallarhorn?

line42.text: You must take me to Bifröst and let me use Gjallarhorn again.

line43.text: It didn't go so well the last time you did.

line44.text: I can recite the galdr. The Aesir will hear me.

line45.text: I don't believe a single word of this nonsense.

line46.text: Rejoice, Egil. Once the plan fails, you can slay the liar.

line47.text: We have to try. Let us head to Bifröst!

line48.text: Here we are, Hvedrung. Perform the galdr or die.

line49.text: Fjalar's cry was heard where the jötunn herdsman dwells.

line50.text: And Gullinkambi yelled in the hall of the slain.

line53.text: Now may the Aesir meet their fate on Vígríd.

line54.text: Your Aesir are gone. Get out of my way.

line56.text: Only those who follow me will survive.

line59.text: We have to go with him!

line61.text: We lost our honor when you chose to spare Hvedrung. But this god came here and finally did the right thing!

line63.text: His power is absolute! Does it mean nothing to you?

line64.text: I won’t let you stand between me and Valhöll! Join me when you come to your senses.

line66.text: Let us not give in to despair just yet. The ancients had foretold the advent of Ragnarök.

line67.text: But they also told us that the surviving gods would gather in Idavoll and rebuild what has been destroyed.

line68.text: What do you have in mind, Svarn?

line69.text: We will meet the remaining Aesir if we find the divine plain of Idavoll.

line70.text: Do you mean we are to abandon Northgard?

line71.text: I'd gladly take a break from the sons of Muspell... not to mention Egil.

line72.text: I won't let this demon or the sons of Muspell chase us.

line73.text: How do you intend to stand against them?

line74.text: There are other clans, now. I have allies.

line75.text: This will never suffice. Why not bring them along?

line76.text: No. I won't abandon my land. And you shouldn't leave either.

line77.text: I have to try, Borgild... but I'll come back for you.

line78.text: I can't promise I'll still be alive by then.

line79.text: We'll find a way to stop Ragnarök. You'll live.

line80.text: And the sooner we depart, the quicker it will be.

line82.text: Fair winds to all of you.

line84.text: Forgive me, my friends, for failing you...

line85.text: With Hvedrung dead, our plan collapses.

line86.text: The sons of Muspell are coming...

line87.text: We're used to them by now. We'll be alright.

line88.text: Let us not lower our guard, though.

Briga.name: Briga
Briga.desc: Rig sets foot on a foreign land, where he finds new hopes and new conflicts.

line0.desc: Befriend the Gayants of Pevele.

line1.desc: Befriend the Gayants of Ostrevent.

line2.desc: Befriend the Gayants of Escaut.

line3.desc: Unify the Gayant clans.

line4.desc: Chase Lothaire out of the region forcibly.

line5.desc: Chase Lothaire out in less than 3 years.

line6.desc: Offer 500 Food to the Gayants using gift routes.

line0.backstory: One of the latest settlers of Northgard, Andhrimnir had assembled a peaceful village that was ravaged by the Eldthursar. With no prospect left on this callous land, he immediately accepted to join our expedition to the mythical Idavoll.
line0.resolution: Discussing with the Gayants, Andhrimnir learned about a prosperous merchant city in the south. Hoping to rebuild his life there, he waved me goodbye and promised to help again if an oportunity arises.

line1.backstory: After fiercely resisting the Eldthursar's assaults, Torfin was starting to accept that his sole strength could not protect his people eternally. The promise of a higher power hidden in Idavoll sufficed to convince him to join our expedition.
line1.resolution: After helping me prevail over Lothaire, Torfin was eager to participate in the demise of Carloman. Seeing mere mortals stand in our way as we try to repel Ragnarök is something Torfin cannot accept.

line0.text: We could hardly recognise our land as we sailed along its coasts. The devastation was spreading.

line1.text: But a few brave warriors were still defending what was left of Northgard. These were the new clans that had settled here after the birth of our kingdom.

line2.text: When we invited them to join our expedition to the promised land, some accepted immediately. Others, like Borgild before them, preferred to keep fighting.

line3.text: We were quite numerous when our fleet ventured into the open sea.

line4.text: But the fury of the World Serpent, sending formidable waves in all directions, soon shattered our group into a multitude of isolated ships.

line5.text: I couldn’t see past my own deck as we were being dispersed across the ocean.

line0.text: We have been chosen, my friends. The land of Idavoll is ours!

line1.text: I know not what Idavoll means, but this land is not yours.

line2.text: A Jötunn! On the land of the Aesir!

line3.text: I am no yotoon, stranger. I am Gelon, ruler of Scarpe and Gayant of the North.

line4.text: Of the North? Well I am Rig, former ruler of Northgard. And I sailed southward for days before reaching this coast.

line5.text: Then the great ending must be coming our way.

line6.text: How do you know that?

line7.text: The weavers of wyrd have warned my ancestors. Men hailing from the north will come, and their apocalypse will follow them.

line8.text: But are we not on the land where the Aesir will celebrate the end of Ragnarök?

line9.text: That is very unlikely. But I do know about the end of Ragnarök.

line10.text: What do you mean?

line11.text: Right now, my people is entangled in an enduring quarrel with Lothaire, the king of Neustria.

line12.text: If we get this man to listen to us, we will be one step closer to this conclusion you are hoping for.

line13.text: How?

line14.text: His family detains something you need.

line15.text: Not for long.

line16.text: Then we have become allies. And you will see that there are many more alliances to forge in this region.

line17.text: I rule one of the four Gayant factions. Lothaire is currently trying to gain influence over the other three.

line18.text: If you manage to federate the factions against him, he will have no choice but to concede defeat.

line19.text: Let us unite your brothers and subdue this unjust king, then!

line20.text: What is that?

line21.text: An invader! The bloodthirsty Northmen are at our doors!

line22.text: Why be so wary of strangers? Most of your enemies are your relatives.

line23.text: Do not insult me! You too should watch out for your own kin before you let foreigners pervade your ranks.

line24.text: I sense a swarm of Gayant warriors coming our way... What have you done, Lothaire?

line25.text: I think you're just not as popular as you used to be, Gelon.

line26.text: You can't blame me for that...

line27.text: I have spent too much time courting these Gayants for you to come here and steal them away from me.

line28.text: You talk as if they belonged to you.

line29.text: They will. And I will make sure you stop interfering.

line30.text: I knew it. You are but a beastly barbarian.

line31.text: I have no qualms about attacking a man who oppresses his people.

line32.text: I will make sure you come to reason and have these qualms very soon.

line33.text: This is worse than I expected... Lothaire must have convinced them that we are dangerous.

line34.text: Let me introduce you to the noble Gayant clan of Pévèle.

line35.text: We have shared good relations for ages, but now that the other two clans are changing allegiance, I am not sure where they stand anymore.

line36.text: This is the ancient Gayant settlement of Ostrevent.

line37.text: Its inhabitants usually stand on neutral grounds, but Lothaire's sudden generosity is slowly corrupting them.

line38.text: You have now met the powerful Gayant faction of Escaut.

line39.text: Our relationship with them has always been tense, and they were the first to accept Lothaire's gifts and emissaries.

line40.text: We are always happy to hear of our friend Gelon. He can count on our support against the Neustrian oppressor!

line41.text: Thank you, Maloré! I will let him know that Pevele is on his side.

line43.text: Ostrevent understands your message. But we Gayants do not share one identity, stranger. Unification does not seem natural.

line44.text: Each clan has its traditions. But all of them would disappear if the Neustrian empire assimilated the Gayants.

line45.text: Yes... We can see why the clans need to stand together. You may tell Gelon that we will join the alliance.

line46.text: You fear Neustria, but what you should fear is Gelon's ambition to rule our clans. Who does he think he is?

line47.text: This is not about Gelon. Neither is it about choosing a leader. This is united resistance.

line48.text: So I see. But you should know that I will not take orders, especially from Gelon.

line49.text: My brother, I bring messages from the clans of Ostrevent and Escaut.

line50.text: It seems that the old alliance has found its vigor back, and that Lothaire's influence over the region has receded.

line51.text: Wonderful news! Now, we need only demonstrate this newfound strength.

line52.text: Do not bother. I have already seen what is happening here.

line53.text: What I long to know is how you, the traditional and unshakable Gayants, fell so easily into the hand of this stranger.

line54.text: We fell into no hand. We merely accepted his help.

line55.text: And may I ask what his interest is in helping the Gayants of the North?

line56.text: He is the man who will assemble the Cross of Vidar. I will accept a truce if you give him the part you detain.

line57.text: And what makes you think I have that sword in my possession?

line58.text: Your family stole it. It is part of the Crown's treasure.

line59.text: And as you can see, I am no longer wearing the Crown.

line61.text: My brother Carloman betrayed me and usurped the throne.

line62.text: It seems you have another king to convince, stranger. And Carloman will not give up the sword unless you take it forcibly.

line64.text: Sadly, you stand no chance against the Neustrian army.

line65.text: But there is one way for you to obtain what you seek.

line67.text: I want my kingdom back. Let us attack Carloman together. Then, you take the healing Jafnharr and I will take the Crown.

line69.text: You will need help finding Carloman and countering his military strategy. No one is better informed on that man than I am.

line70.text: And it only got you this far.

line71.text: Like I told you, I need your help as you need mine.

line72.text: You seem desperate enough to be sincere...

line73.text: Alright. Bring me to this king Carloman.

line74.text: Let us not waste any more time, then! We are headed to Oissel.

line75.text: Thank you, Gelon. I will come back to you when I have the healing Jafnharr.

line76.text: And then I will help you find the other two parts of the Cross.

line77.text: What do you want with me?

line78.text: I stand here with the man who will finally assemble the Cross of Vidar. You must relinquish the fragment you detain.

line79.text: What makes you think I have that sword in my possession?

line80.text: Your family stole it. It is part of the Crown's treasure.

line81.text: And as you can see, I am no longer wearing the Crown.

line83.text: Clueless brute! I mean that my brother Carloman betrayed me and usurped the throne.

line84.text: So now I have another king to defeat.

line85.text: And you stand no chance against the Neustrian army.

line86.text: But there is one way for you to obtain what you seek.

line88.text: I want my kingdom back. Let us attack Carloman together. Then, you take the sword and I take the Crown.

line89.text: You are using me like you tried to use the Gayants.

line90.text: I am just being pragmatic. We share the same goal but neither of us can achieve it alone.

line91.text: You wouldn't even find Carloman. You do not know his weapons, his strategies, nor his character. But I do.

line92.text: And it only got you this far.

line93.text: Like I told you, I need your help as you need mine.

line94.text: You seem desperate enough to be sincere...

line95.text: Alright. Bring me to this king Carloman.

line96.text: Let us head to Oissel, then! We should find him there.

line97.text: This is where our paths diverge, Gelon. I will come back when I have the sword.

line98.text: And then I will help you find the other two parts of the Cross.

line99.text: I found the divine land but I failed... We were so close...

line100.text: I am sorry, Gelon. I failed to protect you.

line101.text: You've made a mistake, stranger. We are now enemies.

Oissel.name: Oissel
Oissel.desc: Lothaire, former king of Neustria, wants to take revenge against the brother who deposed him. He promised Rig a part of the Cross of Vidar in exchange for his assistance.

line0.desc: Force Carloman to surrender.

line1.desc: Build at least 5 forts around Oissel.

line2.desc: Destroy or capture all 5 outer forts of Oissel.

line0.backstory: Although he does not trust Lothaire, Torfin accepted to take part in this battle. Like me, he hopes to retrieve the ancient swords and come back to Northgard with enough power to defeat the Eldthursar.
line0.resolution: Disappointed that I accepted Carloman's proposal, Torfin decided to part ways and go look for the swords by himself. He is determined to get hold of these artifacts without having to take orders from the locals.

line1.backstory: I encountered Brok by chance as he started a journey to find his missing sister. Enslaved by Surtr, the two siblings who reigned on the Horse clan managed to escape, but they were separated by the sea like my comrades and I before them.
line1.resolution: Brok had a conversation with neustrian soldiers who claimed that a woman matching his sister's description was rescued in the northeast. Without delay, he bid me farewell and set off in that direction.

line0.text: So it was true. There was a power in Idavoll that would allow us to end Ragnarök.

line1.text: As the others had all gone missing, I faced my duty alone.

line2.text: I had to find the legendary swords and assemble the Cross of Vidar.

line3.text: As it seemed, I would have to fight more than one king to achieve my goal.

line4.text: But this divine land was just as divided as the one I had just left.

line5.text: And I was determined to use its quarrels to my advantage.

line0.text: We are reaching Oissel, western stronghold of the Neustrian Crown.

line1.text: It is well-guarded. Each entrance is protected by a fort.

line2.text: And there's one more thing.

line3.text: Yes?

line4.text: I must lead this assault.

line5.text: I have lost my crown, but so have you. You have no authority over me.

line6.text: If this is perceived as a barbarian invasion, the local noblemen could unite under Carloman's banner and league against us.

line7.text: However, a nice, brotherly bloodshed...

line8.text: People are used to it. A war between me and Carloman will raise no concerns.

line9.text: How convenient.

line10.text: It is just politics. But you will get what you came for.

line11.text: Alright. I will follow you.

line12.text: That mulish brother of mine, still unable to learn his lesson.

line13.text: You are unfit for the throne, Lothaire. Just give up and be thankful that I spared your life.

line14.text: A decision you shall come to regret very soon.

line15.text: I already regret it.

line16.text: Your brother seems nice.

line17.text: You would have loved our father.

line18.text: We are establishing our domination.

line19.text: There are now more forts outside the stronghold than within it.

line20.text: I had never seen such a cluster of stone buildings... What will you use them for once this war is over?

line21.text: Just because we are at peace does not mean displays of power are superfluous.

line22.text: You are not seriously expecting me to surrender, are you?

line23.text: No, I am still hoping that you will force me to become violent.

line24.text: Fantassins!

line25.text: Interestingly, you would be ordering your own death.

line27.text: Who would take the reins, then? Your primitive friend?

line28.text: No doubt our people would see that as an improvement.

line29.text: Ha ha! I missed your humor.

line30.text: Listen. Couldn't we go back to Saint-Germain together? And figure something out?

line31.text: Figure what out?

line32.text: A way for both of us to get what we want and put an end to this folly.

line33.text: If that's what it takes to get what's mine, I'll follow you to Saint-Germain.

line34.text: Warriors!

line36.text: We will come to an agreement. For Neustria.

line39.text: Lothaire, I honored my part of the deal. It is time for me to receive my payment.

line40.text: You failed. I did not reclaim the kingdom.

line41.text: Your dealings with Carloman are of no interest to me. I want the sword.

line42.text: This is getting annoying. What sword?

line45.text: Stranger. Since you only fulfilled half of your mission, we will grant you the healing Jafnharr on one condition.

line46.text: While the two of you were keeping me busy, I received a message notifying me of an invasion in the southern Leir's region.

line47.text: I want you to eradicate the invaders and claim back the area.

line48.text: Should you succeed, you would not only receive the sword, but also a fief in the region you defended.

line50.text: I think you are using me again.

line51.text: But we are doubling the reward. And you need that sword, don't you?

line52.text: What else can you do anyway?

line53.text: I have to admit... that I have no idea.

line54.text: Splendid! I will personally lend you a ship to help you reach Cantivic.

line55.text: This is not fair... I deserved to get my vengeance.

Cantivic.name: Cantivic
Cantivic.desc: Rig has come to an agreement with Lothaire and Carloman: if he drives away the invader who captured the city of Cantivic, he will receive a fief in Neustria in addition to the sword he was promised.

line0.desc: Buy some food

line1.desc: Use your Harbor to send mercenaries on the outpost.

line2.desc: Don't let Rig's siege decimate your population.

line3.desc: Use your Harbor to explore the coast.

line4.desc: Protect the trading posts on the coast.

line6.desc: Show your resilience with a spectacular feast.

line7.desc: Do not lose a single citizen.

line0.backstory: After leaving us in Briga, Andhrimnir traveled across Neustria and eventually settled in the merchant city he had heard of. There, he found even more oportunities than he had anticipated, but my arrival will adversely affect his commerce.
line0.resolution: Sieges, wars and mercenaries weren't the kind of life Andhrimnir came to Cantivic for. Desiring to find a more peaceful existence, he left the city and went looking for a new place to settle in.

line1.backstory: Fleeing Surtr's yoke, Eir and her people ended up in Neustria, where they faced persecutions once again. Eventually, they found refuge in Cantivic under the protection of a more tolerant ruler.
line1.resolution: It takes more than a siege to discourage the clan of the rat. Eir decided to stay in Cantivic, where Liv's influence ensures that no one will ever dare to question the Norse customs of her people.

line0.text: Lothaire and Carloman were now on equal terms, and I failed to imagine what kind of arrangement the two of them would come to.

line1.text: But their unexpected concord had put me in a position of weakness. I had become a tool in the hands of the Neustrian kingdom.

line2.text: Embarking on one of Carloman's ships, I was sailing toward Cantivic, preparing to free this foreign city from a brutal invader.

line3.text: But another surprise awaited me there.

line4.text: The tyrant I had been commanded to defeat was someone I would never have expected to confront again...

line5.text: It was Liv.

line6.text: She had led a successful invasion of the river's banks, capturing city after city and appointing herself as the Norse queen of Idavoll.

line7.text: Enraged by Northgard’s demise, by Egil's betrayal and by her fear for Borgild, she would not let me stop her that easily.

line0.text: Capturing this city was the easy part. Now, managing it might prove a bit trickier.

line1.text: Cantivic has no means of producing food, and depends entirely on trade. I should keep an eye on my retail outlets.

line2.text: It's good to know you didn't disappear out at sea.

line3.text: Liv! What are you doing here?

line4.text: Capturing cities, mostly.

line5.text: By Freya! I was sent here by the Neustrian kings to drive back an invasion... but you are the invader?

line6.text: Sent? When did you become a homing pigeon?

line7.text: I was promised the sword that will end Ragnarök... in exchange for my cooperation.

line8.text: If you want this sword, why not take it from them?

line9.text: I have battled both kings already, but now that they have joined forces and gained the support of the lesser lords...

line10.text: I've had a taste of the lords and I can tell you they're manageable.

line11.text: Would it be fair to wage war against this people if we can reach an agreement instead? You have been plundering cities, Liv!

line12.text: A diplomatic language everyone understands.

line13.text: You are giving me no choice. I will have to lay siege to this city until you come to your senses and surrender.

line14.text: Besieging Cantivic?

line15.text: There is no road you can block. We get everything from the river.

line16.text: And I have seen on the mainland the trading posts you depend on for food. I can easily interrupt the supply.

line17.text: You will give this land back. And I will end Ragnarök.

line18.text: One trading post down. Let us see how long you can manage without these supplies.

line19.text: Let us see how long it takes me to send my mercenaries and escort your warriors out.

line20.text: Rig will probably send a stronger assault next time.

line21.text: I should build a forge and improve my mercenaries' arsenal if I want to protect those trading posts.

line22.text: Here it is. The coast occupied by Rig.

line23.text: Shall I send raids on these shores... I would get some of the food I need while also discouraging Rig.

line24.text: Two birds with one flaming javelin...

line25.text: What's happening, Rig? I'm supposed to be the one enduring a siege.

line27.text: There's no way we can produce enough food on this island to feed everyone.

line28.text: I should focus on kröwns and buy the supplies I need from my retail outlets.

line29.text: I tried to keep this standoff non-violent, and now you are the one attacking me?

line30.text: It's a shame you don't want to fight. Because I won't hesitate.

line31.text: Have you finally decided to fight back like a true leader?

line32.text: Being around you again has worn out my morals.

line33.text: Well, I think it has become quite clear that your plan won't work.

line34.text: Now tell me about that sword that will end Ragnarök.

line36.text: Just because you are failing to retrieve it doesn't mean I will too.

line37.text: But at what cost would you succeed?

line38.text: That's for me to know. Just tell me what you've learned.

line39.text: There are three swords. Together, they form the Cross of Vidar.

line40.text: The first sword is held by the kings, but I have no idea where the other two are.

line41.text: Fine. I'll find these two swords, slay a king with each of them and reclaim the one they usurped.

line43.text: You are expecting me to become your vassal and follow your orders.

line44.text: Didn't I obey you when you were king? That's just how it goes.

line47.text: The city is in ruins. People won't obey me anymore. I have lost.

line48.text: I must admit I dreamed of a more spectacular death.

line49.text: I failed to protect the trading posts. There's no way the city can survive without food.

Aurelianis.name: Aurelianis
Aurelianis.desc: An unexpected force is rising against Ragnarök: the warmaiden Hildegard is trying to excavate another part of the Cross. But Liv's mercenaries are approaching.

line0.desc: Search the ground for the avenging Harr.

line1.desc: Delve into the northern stone deposit.

line2.desc: Delve into the western stone deposit.

line3.desc: Delve into the southern stone deposit.

line4.desc: Survive the Norse raids.

line5.desc: Build a Monastery on each island.

line0.backstory: After successfully escaping Surtr's claws, Eitria lost track of her brother in a shipwreck and was badly injured. Rescued by nuns, she was noticed by Hildegard who decided to take her under her wing.
line0.resolution: One of Liv's mercenaries, upon recognizing Eitria, immediately revealed that Brok was looking for her in the region of Oissel. This unhoped-for revelation prompted her to leave immediately and go look for her brother.

line1.backstory: It took little time for Andhrimnir to find a new allegiance after the bellicose behaviour of Liv drove him out of Cantivic. A newcomer in the prosperous region of Aurelianis, he wishes to earn Hildegard's trust.
line1.resolution: As soon as he saw Liv setting foot on Aurelianis, Andhrimnir started to fear for his life. He had abandoned this merciless warchief and fraternized with her enemy. Terrified, he returned to Cantivic and acted as if he had never left.

line0.text: Liv had defeated her former king.

line1.text: She seemed unstoppable. And now she was the one undertaking the quest for the Cross of Vidar.

line2.text: From her stronghold of Cantivic, she sent numerous raids across the rivers of Neustria, hunting for the lost swords.

line3.text: But these mercenaries would soon meet with another rising heroine who also coveted the legendary weapons.

line4.text: Through the years, while Lothaire and Carloman competed for the throne of Neustria, their sister Hildegard had devoted herself to the faith.

line5.text: But a dark revelation interrupted her prayers. And this vision was about to derail the fates of more than one kingdom.

line6.text: The twisted and entangled flows of Ragnarök appeared before her. She witnessed their chaotic struggle. She envisioned the war to end all wars.

line7.text: Her vocation had become clear: she would lead this battle. And for this, she needed to assemble the Cross of Vidar.

line0.text: The first will fend off the forces of darkness and clear the earth of all evil.

line1.text: The second will erase our wounds and dissipate our sufferings.

line2.text: The third will free all living souls and introduce a new era of peace.

line3.text: Today, we stand on the ground where the first of these instruments has been preserved through the ages.

line4.text: My fellow worshippers, a sacred relic has been gifted to us.

line5.text: The time has come to prove worthy of this gift by bringing it into the light. So it may save us all.

line6.text: Let us unearth the avenging Harr!

line7.text: We have found the western alluvial deposit.

line8.text: This is the northern alluvial deposit.

line9.text: There! The southern alluvial deposit.

line10.text: The avenging Harr might lie beneath this modest soil.

line11.text: The northern vessels! My vision was veracious, they are coming at last!

line12.text: But... What are they doing now? This is not what was supposed to happen!

line13.text: I cannot let it erode my faith. We must hold on.

line14.text: Another raid is coming. More blood will be spilled today.

line15.text: If this keeps happening, my kin will never agree to stand alongside this northern people.

line16.text: And we will be doomed.

line17.text: Pious people of Neustria, our faith is being tested.

line18.text: Do not yield to despair!

line19.text: A brighter day awaits us at the end of this ordeal.

line20.text: And we will share it with the mortal souls who now stand as our enemies.

line21.text: We have fully explored the first deposit.

line22.text: We have taken a step in the right direction.

line23.text: But this is merely the beginning of our efforts.

line24.text: We have delved into the earth with unfading tenacity.

line25.text: Our confidence must strengthen with every step we take into the unknown.

line26.text: Your Highness, we may have found the relic!

line27.text: Magnificent!

line28.text: It really is the avenging Harr... We have been blessed.

line29.text: Please unearth it with extreme care.

line30.text: Party's over. Tell me what happened to my mercenaries and I might spare a few lives.

line31.text: I was expecting you, northern sovereign. You are most welcome.

line32.text: I seriously doubt it. Just answer my question.

line33.text: We have protected the avenging Harr from your misguided troops.

line34.text: Fair enough. You tried. But now I'll take it.

line35.text: I know you need this sword, but you also need my help.

line36.text: The help of a delirious mystic is the last thing I need.

line37.text: Judging by the behaviour of your mercenaries, you do not have a clear idea of how to obtain the other two relics.

line38.text: Furthermore, the healing Jafnharr happens to be in my brother's possession.

line39.text: Nonsense! That sword is held by the king of Neustria.

line41.text: ... I'm beginning to understand how you could help me.

line43.text: You can take the avenging Harr. And as soon as it is unearthed, we shall head to Saint-Germain and reclaim its sister.

line44.text: That's a very reasonable offer. I can't refuse!

line45.text: Do not lose hope, my fellows. I have failed, but Neustria will see the light.

line46.text: We have lost one of the settlements! The search cannot continue.

SaintGermain.name: Saint-Germain
SaintGermain.desc: Liv and Hildegard embark on a journey to assemble the Cross. Now, they must convince Carloman to relinquish his part of the relic.

line0.desc: Find a way out of the captured city.

line1.desc: Don't let Egil's troops get you.

line2.desc: Find two sails in the old fishery's crates.

line3.desc: Take back Saint-Germain from Egil.

line4.desc: Eliminate an entire patrol.

line5.desc: Rid the city of Egil's troops.

line0.backstory: Liv met Torfin in the outskirts of the city, where he had planned an attack to reclaim the healing Jafnharr. But as some recent events had caused his scheme to fall apart, he accepted to work with her as a last resort.
line0.resolution: Egil's evasion was one deception too many for Torfin. Unimpressed by the sword Hildegard had retrieved, and feeling that this quest was leading nowhere, he resolved to come back to Northgard and fight Surtr with his bare hands.

line1.backstory: Detained by Saint-Germain's new protector, Signy used recent events as an oportunity to escape. The circumstances of her imprisonment are unclear, but she will offer Hildegard her help in a critical moment.
line1.resolution: After evading Egil's guardhouse, Signy had only one thought in mind: retaliation. Suspecting that he fled to the north in an attempt to leave Neustria, she acompanies Liv on her journey. Chasing separate prays, they will travel side by side.

line0.text: Hildegard and Liv had made a first step toward their common ambition. The Avenging Harr was theirs.

line1.text: Now, they would have to meet Carloman in Saint-Germain and convince him to draw out the healing Jafnharr from the Crown’s treasure.

line2.text: But the situation in the capital was quite different from what they had imagined.

line3.text: Lothaire, dissatisfied with Carloman’s concessions, had led an uprising and stolen the sword.

line4.text: Weakened by his brother's betrayal, and cautiously observing his sister’s growing influence, Carloman was concerned.

line5.text: And his latest attempt at protecting himself had entrapped him in a dark alliance.

line0.text: My very dear sister, I am glad to see you again.

line1.text: Brother... war has kept us apart for too long. I rejoice with you at this reunion.

line2.text: But it is with a grave heart that I come to you today, for I am on a holy mission.

line3.text: I would expect nothing less of you.

line4.text: You may already know that a cataclysm is upon us.

line5.text: I heard it said.

line6.text: However, the Cross of Vidar can preserve us, and I am going to assemble it. For this, I need the healing Jafnharr.

line7.text: Why is that mediocre heirloom all anyone can think about, lately?

line8.text: What do you mean?

line9.text: I cannot give you the sword, Hilda. Your brother ran away with it. And he also took the better part of my army with him.

line10.text: He stole the sword?

line11.text: Frankly, that is the least of my concerns. The man has an appetite for revolt and betrayal.

line12.text: Things do not look good, here. And did you know that Nominoë is leading yet another uprising in Kernev?

line13.text: I cannot face all these threats at once. I had to hire a Norse mercenary for my own protection.

line14.text: Show yourself, Egil.

line15.text: Is something wrong, my lord?

line16.text: I just wanted to introduce you to my sister, Hildegard.

line17.text: It is a pleasure to meet you, Egil. It turns out that I too have forged an alliance with a Norse sovereign.

line18.text: Have you?

line19.text: Have you, Hilda? Why?

line20.text: Surtr was right... It's now or never.

line21.text: What are you...?

line22.text: Ha!

line23.text: Carloman!

line24.text: Guards! The moment has come!

line25.text: Capture the witch and take over the city!

line26.text: You need to flee, your Highness! We'll cover you!

line27.text: But I must...

line28.text: You must run!

line29.text: Quick! Where can I go?

line30.text: They are coming right ahead! I am lost!

line31.text: My only chance is to hide in the tall grass.

line32.text: They are gone, my queen. But you should not stay in here!

line33.text: The great door is guarded! How can I leave?

line34.text: There is a path through the bog. It leads to an old creak where you should find a boat.

line35.text: I can hide you until the night comes and the patrols get tired.

line36.text: May you be blessed, my sister!

line37.text: It is time... the creak should be at the eastern end of that path.

line38.text: My torch will help me find my way, but it makes me quite noticeable. I must remain wary.

line40.text: I will have to clear a path through the brambles.

line41.text: Blazes! I was hoping to find a boat here...

line42.text: I cannot give up now. Maybe I can salvage a raft from the wreckage.

line43.text: That vessel should be sturdy enough... but I cannot find any sail.

line44.text: Surely there must be a few of them in the old fishery's supplies.

line45.text: I will use whatever I can find in these crates.

line46.text: Here! These pieces of fabric are wide enough.

line47.text: That should do it. I have no time left anyway!

line48.text: I don't mean to pry, Hildegard, but what are you doing on a boat?

line49.text: We have to capture the city.

line50.text: I don't see why not, but that's unexpected.

line51.text: A man named Egil was here. Upon learning that we had met, he killed my brother and sent his guards after me.

line55.text: I give you my word that we'll chase him out of here.

line56.text: There you are! Didn't you bring your friends with you?

line57.text: It seems maintaining friendships is not my forte.

line58.text: That makes two of us. Now die!

line59.text: We have taken the city back. But I see no trace of that man.

line60.text: He's nowhere to be found. The coward must have fled when he felt the wind turn.

line61.text: I have no appetite for vengeance anyway.

line62.text: After he slayed your brother before your eyes?

line63.text: Our people are safe again. Carloman made mistakes, but this is what mattered most to him too.

line64.text: And I guess that burden falls upon you now.

line65.text: Indeed. After Lothaire's treason... I am now queen.

line66.text: And what about him? He took off with what we were looking for.

line67.text: Would you agree to look for him and retrieve the sword?

line68.text: Sure, I can do that. But why aren't you coming?

line69.text: Carloman mentioned a revolt in Kernev.

line71.text: A conflict that should have been resolved ages ago. I must go there without delay and make things right.

line72.text: I'll hit the road, then! And come back with Jafnharr.

line73.text: Just one more thing... I may need the avenging Harr. Just for this expedition.

line74.text: Someone's gonna have some fun while I'm out there running errands!

line75.text: Not exactly. But I promise to return it the next time we meet.

line76.text: It's alright. You've earned my trust.

line79.text: I wish I had died in a less humiliating place.

Jengland.name: Jengland
Jengland.desc: While Liv and Hildegard were reconquering Saint-Germain, Nominoë, lord of the occupied Kernev, led an assault to claim back his land.

line0.desc: Clear the first outpost.

line1.desc: Find the Neustrian fort.

line2.desc: Capture the Neustrian fort.

line3.desc: Raise an army of 10 units or more.

line4.desc: Control every outpost in the region.

line0.backstory: As the vikings of Cantivic started adopting Neustrian beliefs, they viewed Eir's rituals as more and more deranging. Forced to flee once again, she found a friendlier welcome in Kernev and became an ally to Nominoë.
line0.resolution: With this victory, Eir gained the trust of Nominoë and got the confirmation that Kernev would welcome her people. Now, she will do whatever it takes to protect this land.

line1.backstory: Coming from the distant steppes, Grif is seeking vengeance after repelling a Neustrian invasion on their land. On the coasts of Kernev, they were convinced by Nominoë to unite against their common enemy: the Neustrian Crown.
line1.resolution: Upon learning about the Lothaire's getaway, Grif decided to go north and hunt him down, for they are still determined to punish the former king's attempted invasion.

line0.text: Hildegard had no time to grieve her unwise brother. She was the new queen of Neustria, and the kingdom was at war.

line1.text: She sent Liv to retrieve the healing Jafnharr from Lothaire and scurried to the plains of Jengland.

line2.text: There, she expected to find a familiar but menacing figure: the lord of Kernev, Nominoë.

line3.text: For years, Nominoë had tried to free his people from the Crown of Neustria.

line4.text: Now, following the quarrels and invasions that had torn the kingdom apart, he was finally in a position of power.

line5.text: But his most valuable advantage had yet to be revealed.

line0.text: Here we are, Svarn. Treading the soil my people once lived on and feeling the wind that used to fill our sails.

line1.text: I understand that the few locals still lingering here are living under Carloman's rule.

line2.text: And this cannot continue.

line3.text: Neustria always outnumbered us, but the ongoing quarrels and invasions on their side of the continent have made them weak.

line4.text: Any news from your Gayant allies, by the way?

line5.text: Gelon has already launched his assault with the help of your men. Meanwhile, Barbetorte is leading our troops in Saint-Suliac.

line6.text: That should keep Carloman busy while we reclaim the land you're standing on.

line7.text: What's our plan?

line8.text: Neustrian guards occupy every inhabited region and exploit my kin.

line9.text: If we free those workers, they will help us get farther.

line10.text: In which direction?

line11.text: A few miles west stands the fort that ensures Neustria's control of the region. We must capture it.

line12.text: Just us against an army? The odds don't seem in our favour...

line13.text: We have a whole people with us, Svarn. The locals want Carloman out even more than we do.

line14.text: Let's not make them wait any longer, then!

line15.text: We have now claimed a first outpost!

line16.text: I expect the Neustrian army to strike back... but we have a nice view over the region now. We will see them coming!

line17.text: And as long as we control an outpost, its workers will support our effort with resources!

line18.text: If we follow this path to the north, we should reach another outpost. And a church.

line19.text: That would cement our position in the region.

line20.text: Indeed. That would be the safest way to go if we're not ready for a direct attack yet.

line21.text: There! Isn't that Carloman's fort?

line22.text: No doubt. This monument of death casts its shadow over the whole region.

line23.text: Not for long.

line24.text: But I think they might have noticed us... Can you see these warriors coming in our direction?

line25.text: We will welcome them!

line26.text: The situation is becoming dire. We don't have enough food to sustain our expedition.

line27.text: We must maintain contact with the regions where the workers dwell.

line28.text: If we're cut from the population, we won't make it.

line29.text: This is a great day for the land of Kernev. A terrible yoke has just been broken.

line30.text: What are your plans, now? What will our next battle be?

line31.text: My friend, I have a feeling that the battle is coming right at us. Look around you.

line32.text: Who are you, and what is your army doing on my land?

line33.text: I am Hildegard, queen of Neustria.

line34.text: Queen? Was Carloman slayed in battle by Barbetorte? By Gelon?

line35.text: Carloman never got a chance to fight this war.

line36.text: And I come to inform you that I do not intend to fight it either.

line37.text: I have no interest in retaliating against you or taking back this land.

line39.text: You have won your independence, and I will do nothing to deprive you of it again.

line40.text: What happened to the unified Neustrian empire your brothers decimated us over?

line41.text: I too seek unification. That is why I am proposing an alliance.

line42.text: You are neither Lothaire nor Carloman, I give you that. But still, your family has persecuted mine for decades.

line43.text: A late overture, given just in time to save yourself from our avenging swords, won't make us forget that.

line44.text: I hear you. And I am willing to discuss Neustria's debt to Kernev. But for now, there is a certain urgency to my proposal.

line45.text: A threat is coming that will require us to join forces.

line47.text: I can hear in your voice that you already know. Did you tell Nominoë?

line49.text: Then the two of you probably discussed the Cross of Vidar already.

line50.text: We have found the avenging Harr, and we are pursuing the healing Jafnharr.

line51.text: I know the last sword, the liberating Thridi, to be somewhere in Kernev.

line52.text: So that's why you needed us. That explains the conciliatory gesture.

line53.text: The matter is serious, my friend. I am asking you as a favor to take it into consideration.

line54.text: You're in luck. I trust Svarn enough to follow his advice.

line55.text: If you order the removal of all the Neustrian troops in Kernev, we will get that sword.

line56.text: This will make you twice as victorious.

line57.text: I will see you on the day Ragnarök ends.

line58.text: I'm sorry, Nominoe. I wish I could have been more helpful to your people.

line59.text: I failed my people... I am dying without honor.

line60.text: They are retaliating! We must defend our position.

line61.text: The assault came from the west. Shall we explore this area, we would probably find the Neustrian fort!

Ploidran.name: Ploidran
Ploidran.desc: Guided by Gelon, Svarn and Nominoë are looking for the last part of the Cross.

line0.desc: Mine the Tarasque to retrieve Thridi.

line1.desc: Do not recruit a single miner (gnomes don't count).

line2.desc: Do not let a single miner die.

line0.backstory: Exploring the western lands, Eitria came across the Gayants, who had met Brok in Kernev and allowed the siblings to exchange messages. Before leaving for the coast where her brother awaits her, she honors her debt towards Gelon by helping retrieve Thridi.
line0.resolution: After this battle, Eitria and Gelon were even. The young woman could now scurry to the north and rejoin her brother. But as she prepared her departure, she heard Brok calling her name. Gelon had guided him here.

line1.backstory: Now determined to stay in Kernev, Eir is following Nominoë. Neither of them is especially interested in saving Neustria, but both would make any sacrifice to ensure that they can live freely in Kernev.
line1.resolution: Eir had been hoping to settle in the populous region of Jengland, but her fascination for the powerful and immortal Tarasque changed these plans. The monster is now an object of adoration for the clan of the rat, which became known as the guardian of Ploidran.

line0.text: Hildegard had seen what her brothers had not: there was more than one people in Neustria.

line1.text: And now that its struggle for independence had come to an end, the people of Kernev could become a key ally.

line2.text: Svarn and Nominoë were now part of the coalition against Ragnarök. They would retrieve the last part of the Cross.

line3.text: And as Hildegard had anticipated, Kernev’s good relationship with the Gayants was a tremendous asset, for Gelon was able to guide the two heroes to the sword.

line0.text: We are close. I can already scent the creature.

line1.text: How is it that you know so much about these antique swords?

line2.text: Vidar was the son of Gridr. And Gridr is the ancestor of all Gayants. The story of the swords is our legacy.

line3.text: But why were they named after that child?

line4.text: His destiny was to save us all... but he died. And the Norns created the Cross to fulfill the predictions they had weaved for him.

line5.text: The Norns? What were they doing in Kernev?

line6.text: Here. This is the Tarasque.

line7.text: Gelon, I cannot see a thing.

line8.text: And you would rather not. When the creature wakes up, the only thing you will see is doom.

line9.text: I'm starting to understand why Hildegard sent us here instead of coming herself.

line10.text: And I will not take part in this folly either. I have my own mission to fulfill right now.

line11.text: It's alright, Gelon. Thank you for guiding us here.

line12.text: Whoever your gods are, may they protect you both!

line13.text: Let's not waste any time! We'll extract the sword while the beast is asleep.

line14.text: Miners!

line15.text: Retreat!

line16.text: Understood! We will prepare and come back with soldiers!

line17.text: Is it... eating the stone?

line18.text: At least, now we know where it gets its strengths from.

line19.text: More stone! I thought the deposits were depleted.

line20.text: We'll need to keep our miners ready throughout the fight!

line21.text: These deposits are different! Is it eating iron now?

line22.text: And the new diet seems to have strengthened the beast... We'd better try to improve our gear too!

line23.text: Now! Let's mine it while it's asleep!

line24.text: We're about halfway there!

line25.text: Splendid!

line27.text: Behold this wonder. The liberating Thridi.

line28.text: It's not every day you extract a mythical weapon from a monster's back.

line29.text: Indeed! This one awaited you for ages.

line30.text: Gelon! What are the news?

line31.text: We have explored the coast and found something rather concerning.

line32.text: Egil and his master have settled on the nearby island of Nermoster. They are raising an army and planning an attack on Kernev and Neustria.

line33.text: Do you mean... Surtr is here?

line34.text: We must attack them first!

line35.text: Not before Liv comes back. Not before we have the three swords.

line36.text: So this is the moment when the power of the Cross will be needed?

line37.text: This is the moment Vidar came to life and died for.

line38.text: The age of torment will culminate and end with our next battle.

line39.text: But until Liv brings us the healing Jafnharr, we will have to raise troops, sharpen our weapons... and wait.

line40.text: Let us just hope nothing happened to her.

line41.text: I cannot believe it. So many fates depended on us...

line42.text: This creature... We were no match for it.

Brissarthe.name: Brissarthe
Brissarthe.desc: In her quest for the sword Lothaire has stolen, Liv comes across some unexpected obstacles.

line0.desc: Locate and defeat Egil's army.

line1.desc: Reach the fountain and talk to Lothaire.

line2.desc: Make Signy send wolves at 4 of Egil's troops.

line3.desc: Collect at least 10 pouches during blizzards.

line0.backstory: Signy followed Liv's journey across Neustria, following Lothaire's tracks and hoping to take her revenge against Egil. And while the two warriors undeniably get along, it is becoming clear to Liv that Signy is hiding something.
line0.resolution: As soon as Signy heard that Surtr had joined Egil off the coast of Neustria, her face darkened. She apologized, but Liv had no idea why. And when the time came to leave Brissarthe, Signy had disappeared.

line1.backstory: Grif had no trouble finding Lothaire's tracks, but several other trails seemed to follow them. Eventually, the falconer came across Liv, and while they didn't exactly agree on what to do of Lothaire, they were both determined to capture him.
line1.resolution: With Lothaire dead, there was no more vengeance to take. And as it seemed, Hildegard's rise to power had dissipated the risk of a second assault. Grif saluted Liv calmy without a word and left the continent, never to be seen again.

line0.text: Svarn and Nominoë had braved the Tarasque. Two of the sacred swords were now in the alliance's possession.

line1.text: But the healing Jafnharr was still missing and Liv’s absence was becoming a subject of concern.

line2.text: What had happened to her?

line3.text: Following Lothaire’s tracks, she had traveled to the confines of Neustria. But a familiar obstacle started slowing her down.

line4.text: When she sensed this blizzard rising over Neustria, she knew something unusual was happening.

line5.text: It was clear now that more surprises awaited her.

line0.text: By the jackdaw's bald head, how could this storm rise so fast?

line1.text: Neustria's climate seemed pretty mild, until now...

line2.text: Impressive, isn't it?

line3.text: When I see all that snow, I'm reminded of our cold friend Borgild.

line4.text: I knew something was off... What's with the blizzard?

line5.text: I expected you to follow me here, so I thought I'd make you feel at home.

line6.text: I was following Lothaire. I want the sword.

line7.text: That makes us rivals.

line8.text: Perfect. I'll have to finish you, then!

line9.text: What are you doing? Don't interrupt us!

line10.text: You must come right away.

line11.text: Seriously? Now?!

line12.text: They found Nermoster. An assault is expected.

line13.text: I can't believe it!

line14.text: This fight will have to wait, Liv! I'll see you in Hel!

line15.text: ... First the blizzard, and now this.

line16.text: What's happening here?

line17.text: Alright, troops! Remember our distant land?

line18.text: This will be one of those Northgard winters: cold, harsh and feeling like eternity.

line19.text: But we'll endure this blizzard like we endured Fimbulvinter!

line20.text: Brace yourselves, people of the North!

line21.text: Another blizzard is coming and we'll show the southerners how to handle it!

line22.text: The blizzard seems to be coming earlier each year...

line23.text: I don't like this. We'd better hurry!

line24.text: I've never seen anything like that! If this continues...

line25.text: We'll be trapped in a neverending storm.

line26.text: Egil's warriors... and those draconic abominations!

line27.text: Come on, Egil! Show yourself!

line28.text: What... Is that Lothaire?

line29.text: The sword shouldn't be far, then.

line30.text: Let's hurry up and get to him!

line31.text: You!

line32.text: Stop paddling and tell me where the sword is!

line33.text: The fountain of Barenton has authority over the celestial tides.

line34.text: I hid Jafnharr into its waters and the snow started falling.

line35.text: But the frost didn't stop their ships... They took the sword and left me to die.

line37.text: Why is that sword so important, all of a sudden?

line38.text: Hildegard says it was crafted by the Norns for Vidar, son of Odin. She believes it has the power to stop Ragnarök.

line39.text: I have no idea what any of those things are.

line42.text: Your brother got killed. Your sister became queen.

line44.text: Tell her they are in Nermoster now.

line46.text: You've got a tough battle ahead of you.

line47.text: Don't worry, fallen king. We'll save your land.

Nermoster.name: Nermoster
Nermoster.desc: The last sword was taken to the island of Nermoster, from which emanates an ominous glow.

line0.desc: Protect [Hero08]'s shore.

line1.desc: Protect [Nominoe]'s shore.

line2.desc: Protect [Maiden03]'s shore.

line3.desc: Capture the second shore.

line4.desc: Capture the third shore.

line6.desc: Reclaim the healing Jafnharr before the beast breaks free.

line0.text: Surtr had gotten hold of the healing Jafnharr.

line1.text: The fiend had followed us and used our expedition to expand his conquest beyond the land of Northgard.

line2.text: Hidden on the island of Nermoster, he was now preparing a brutal assault on Neustria and Kernev.

line3.text: But three peoples were united against that threat.

line4.text: And although one sword was still missing, the avenging Harr and the liberating Thridi were giving hope to Norsemen and Neustrians alike.

line5.text: Many paths were about to cross on this island. The battle of Nermoster would soon settle the fate of our three kingdoms.

line0.text: This is worse than I imagined. These dragon men are everywhere.

line1.text: We can't let that intimidate us! We have two legendary swords.

line2.text: But they have the third one.

line3.text: Not for long, right? What's our plan?

line4.text: Svarn and I have already installed a first settlement on this coast.

line5.text: We will mend your wounds if needed, and make sure our troops coming from the continent can safely debark here.

line6.text: There are several shores like this one along the path that leads to Surtr's camp.

line7.text: If we manage to capture them, we'll be able to send reinforcements there too.

line8.text: As we get further and capture new shores, we will also have to protect the ones we already control.

line9.text: But if we need to move fast, the tall grass should help us avoid unnecessary fights.

line10.text: I see you've had the time to think this through!

line11.text: Now, before the battle starts, I shall give you back the avenging Harr.

line12.text: I cannot accept after failing to retrieve Jafnharr. You unearthed that sword. You should be the one to carry it.

line13.text: Thank you, Liv. I accept this honor.

line14.text: Strangely, I started feeling the sword's powers intensifying as we moved closer to Nermoster...

line15.text: So it was true! You're so impatient to die that you came to us by yourselves.

line16.text: Aren't you the one who followed us across the ocean?

line17.text: Liv! So you made it too... that means you're all here now.

line18.text: What do you mean?

line19.text: That you'll all burn in the pyre!

line20.text: The final ordeal has begun! Brace yourselves!

line21.text: I'll defend this shore! If you ever need to retreat, you can find shelter here.

line22.text: We'll try to intercept the swarms as we move on to the next spot!

line23.text: I want to fight! Let me go!

line24.text: Surtr won't allow it. Everyone on board, now!

line25.text: Wait!

line26.text: Things are getting weirder and weirder. This is not the first time I witness that kind of scene.

line27.text: I have a bad feeling about it.

line28.text: Once more, you disappoint me.

line29.text: You never let me put my life into the fight! Why?

line30.text: That life is way too precious.

line31.text: Nonsense!

line32.text: Shut up!

line33.text: This whole thing has dragged on for too long.

line34.text: I shall put an end to it.

line35.text: Things are about to get serious. Can you defend this shore?

line36.text: Who do you think I am?

line37.text: Then I will capture the last one, and we will meet again soon!

line38.text: As we moved closer, another one of Harr's powers revealed itself. Hopefully, that will help me face the giants.

line39.text: You long to know why I have preserved that miserable life of yours, Egil.

line40.text: Today, that question will be answered as you finally serve your true purpose.

line42.text: I give you the opportunity to avenge your honor. Kill that man.

line44.text: You spineless fool! If not for your honor, then do it to save your life.

line46.text: Then I will have to kill you first, fallen king.

line48.text: I owed you one, Rig. Now, we're even.

line50.text: Stop defying me, scion of Loki!

line51.text: That man is the one who did it! Rig killed your herald!

line52.text: You are an instrument of Ragnarök, just as I am!

line53.text: By Tyr, what can that be?

line54.text: The beast. The one that shall only be defeated by Vidar's power.

line55.text: But we haven't found the third part of the Cross yet!

line56.text: It's only a matter of time! We must keep faith and continue to move north.

line57.text: But be prepared! The beast does not want us there.

line59.text: I found it... I finally found Jafnharr.

line61.text: But he has the third sword!

line63.text: It will be alright, now. Jafnharr saved your life.

line64.text: I am still weak... You must take the sword.

line65.text: I'm always here to help the feeble.

line66.text: Svarn, Gelon... can you bring him to safety?

line68.text: The rest of us will have to bear the Cross and face the Beast. We cannot wait.

line71.text: We must not let its greatness intimidate us!

line72.text: We are bearing the Cross of Vidar. A divine power has been entrusted to us.

line73.text: Divine or not, we've come too far not to put up a great fight!

line74.text: We are three peoples marching together. Nothing can stand against us.

line78.text: Too many of their warriors are reaching our shore! We are struggling!

line79.text: I appreciate that you trust me, but please don't let all the enemies into my outpost!

line80.text: We are struggling, here! You are not stopping enough of them!

line81.text: Take courage, my friends! Here come the reinforcements!

line82.text: You looked like you needed some help. Don't thank me!

line83.text: My men want to be part of the fun. They're coming to assist you!

line84.text: I'm sorry, my friends. They were too numerous.

line85.text: My time has come. I have failed.

line86.text: Dying like the Aesir died... in a way, that's not so bad.

line87.text: We were so close... and yet, I failed...

line88.text: At least, I died a free man.
